Url.Title: Welcome to Online Help for Universal Analysis
Url.Abstract: Introducing TA Instruments powerful tool for analyzing data obtained from any of the following instruments:

Url.Title: TA Instruments Trademarks and Patents
Url.Abstract: TA Instruments Trademarks and Patents The following references apply to the information presented in this document.

Url.Title: Getting assistance while you work
Url.Abstract: Getting Assistance While You Work To see information about a tool bar button, position the mouse pointer over the button until the text appears.

Url.Title: Using the Main Menu
Url.Abstract: Using the Main Menu After you have opened a data file using the File/Open menu option and accepted the data file information displayed, the main menu displays more options. These options allow you to rescale and analyze the data, as well as perform other functions. Click on the name of the menu below to obtain further information.

Url.Title: Using the Zoom Box
Url.Abstract: Using the Zoom Box You can easily expand a portion of the curve for analysis using the mouse. To zoom in on a particular portion of the curve for analysis, follow these steps:

Url.Title: Tips on Using Markers
Url.Abstract: Tips on Using Markers Markers are lines that are used to select points on a graph during rescaling and analysis operations. Depending on the action and/or the file, markers will be displayed as a single vertical line or as a set of vertical and horizontal lines.

Url.Title: File Menu
Url.Abstract: File Menu Use the File menu to open a data file and perform various functions such as closing any open windows, saving analyses, remove analysis results, etc.

Url.Title: Open Menu
Url.Abstract: Open Menu Use the Open menu item to open a file. You can open a TA Instruments data file for analysis using the Universal Analysis program or you can launch applications associated with specific file extensions. For example, you can open Microsoft® Word files containing a ".doc" extension directly from Universal Analysis using this window to launch the Microsoft Word program.

Url.Title: Quick Open
Url.Abstract: Quick Open Check the Quick Open box to open and plot the data file immediately after the Open button is clicked, without first viewing the Data File Information window for that file.

Url.Title: Close Menu
Url.Abstract: Close Menu Use the Close option to close the current window.

Url.Title: Remove Analysis Menu
Url.Abstract: Remove Analysis Menu Use the Remove Analysis option to delete the saved analysis record stored in the data file.

Url.Title: Save Analysis Menu
Url.Abstract: Save Analysis Menu Use the Save Analysis option to save either just the current analysis (Analysis Only) or the analysis and the data file (Analysis and Data) for future recall. When you select this option, the standard Save As window is displayed, allowing you to select a filename and location.

Url.Title: Save Session Menu
Url.Abstract: Save Session Menu Use the Save Session function to save the current state of the program, including all settings, open file information, and data read into memory. This function can also be used to save the analysis results from multiple data files into a single session file. This way you can turn off or restart your computer, or let someone else use the program, without losing the work you have already done. You can later restore the program to the state it was in when you saved the session.

Url.Title: Login/Logout
Url.Abstract: Login/Logout The Advantage Integrity Instrument Control and Universal Analysis programs are part of the closed system for creation and storage of electronic records. As such, each person must log in for identification and permission to use the system.

Url.Title: Edit Parameter Block Window
Url.Abstract: Edit Parameter Block Window Use this window to make an exact copy of the current data file and to edit the parameter block information that is stored in the new file as follows:

Url.Title: Options (Main)
Url.Abstract: Options (Main) Use the Options function to set up the main program options available. See also:

Url.Title: Export Plot
Url.Abstract: Export Plot Use the Export Plot option to export the current graph to the clipboard for retrieval in another program, or to export the graph to a file, plotter, or printer.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Initialization Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Initialization Page Use this window to specify the file path for the initialization (.ini) file(s) that will be used to define program preferences by the Universal Analysis program and to specify localization language settings.

Url.Title: Export Data File
Url.Abstract: Export Data File Use the Export Data File option to export the file signals and/or the plot signals in the form of a binary data file, an ASCII data file, or a spreadsheet text file.

Url.Title: Print command
Url.Abstract: Print command Use this command to print a document. This command presents a Print dialog box where you may specify the range of pages to be printed, the number of copies, the destination printer, and other printer setup options. The format of the printed plot is determined by the current settings for the Printer Destination on the Export Plot window.

Url.Title: Print Setup
Url.Abstract: Print Setup Use this command to select a printer and a printer connection. This command presents a Print Setup dialog box, where you specify the printer and its connection.

Url.Title: Exit
Url.Abstract: Exit Use this command to end your Thermal Advantage Universal Analysis session. Thermal Advantage prompts you to save documents with unsaved changes.

Url.Title: Edit Menu
Url.Abstract: Edit Menu Use the Edit menu to perform various editing functions on the current graph or spreadsheet.

Url.Title: Copy Plot
Url.Abstract: Copy Plot Use the Copy Plot option to copy the plot displayed to the clipboard for retrieval by other applications. The format on the copied plot is determined by the current settings for the Clipboard Destination on the Export Plot window.

Url.Title: Paste
Url.Abstract: Paste Use this procedure to retrieve information from the clipboard to the spreadsheet view. To paste:

Url.Title: Select All Labels
Url.Abstract: Select All Labels Use the Select All Labels option to highlight all of the analysis results and annotations displayed on the graph. You can then move them to a different position on the graph or delete them.

Url.Title: File Information
Url.Abstract: File Information Use the File Information option to modify the parameters on the Data File Information Window. When you select this menu item, the File Information Window is displayed to allow you to edit the information contained in the data file. If only text items are changed, the data in memory is not reloaded (i.e., current analyses are not lost). If any other items are changed, the data is reread from the file so the new values (e.g.,size, cell constant) can be applied. These changes are not saved to the original data file.

Url.Title: Annotate
Url.Abstract: Annotate Use the Annotate option to access the Annotation Window, which allows you to place text on the graph.

Url.Title: Annotate/Inset View Pop-up Menu
Url.Abstract: Annotate/Inset View Pop-up Menu Use this pop-up menu, after an annotation (label) or inset view has been created, to edit or delete the annotation or inset. Position the pointer over the annotation/inset view and click the right mouse button to display this menu.

Url.Title: Resolution
Url.Abstract: Resolution Use the Resolution menu item to set the numeric resolution of an individual result value that is displayed on the plot and in the reports generated by the Universal Analysis program. When you select Resolution, the Label Resolution window is displayed.

Url.Title: Add Scale Bar
Url.Abstract: Add Scale Bar Use the Add Scale Bar function to add a labeled I-bar to denote a unit of distance to the plot. When you select this item the Scale Bar window is displayed.

Url.Title: Adjust Last Result
Url.Abstract: Adjust Last Result Use the Adjust Last Result option to fine tune the position of the analysis tangent lines. This option is available after you have performed an operation such as:

Url.Title: Delete Results
Url.Abstract: Delete Results Use the Delete Results option to remove analysis results and annotations from the graph displayed.

Url.Title: Exclude Data
Url.Abstract: Exclude Data Use the Exclude Data option to remove the selected range of data points from the data used for your analysis. It does not alter the data file. The Exclude Data functions can be used to:

Url.Title: Analysis Log Comment
Url.Abstract: Analysis Log Comment Use this menu item to access the Analysis Log Comment window, which allows you to add a comment to the analysis log file for the current data file. The comment is identified in the log by " / / " in front of the entered text.

Url.Title: Audit Trail Comment
Url.Abstract: Audit Trail Comment Use this menu item to access the Audit Trail Comment window, which allows you to add a comment to the Integrity Audit Trail for the current data file. The comment is described in the Audit Trail as a "User Comment."

Url.Title: Rescale Menu
Url.Abstract: Rescale Menu The Rescale menu options allow you to change the limit points and analysis range. You can change the axis scaling and zoom in on the portion of the graph that will be analyzed using these options.

Url.Title: Zoom Box Pop-up Menu
Url.Abstract: Zoom Box Pop-up Menu After you draw the zoom box, you can right click inside the dotted lines to display the pop-up menu containing the following items. Click on the name for further information on that topic.

Url.Title: Manually Rescaling
Url.Abstract: Manually Rescaling The Manual rescale option is used to select exact start and stop limits for the x- and y-axes to reduce or expand the graph, and to change the label and tick intervals.

Url.Title: Rescaling in the X/Y Direction
Url.Abstract: Rescaling in the X/Y Direction You can change the position of the curve in the X or Y direction using either of two methods:

Url.Title: Zoom Out
Url.Abstract: Zoom Out When you select the Zoom Out option, you will reduce the image size and make it appear smaller. Click on this option once to move out one level.

Url.Title: Previous Limits
Url.Abstract: Previous Limits The Previous Limits option redraws the graph as it appeared before the most recent scale changes. Only the scaling options selected from the Rescale menu are affected by this menu option, any changes made in color or annotation are not affected. Selecting Previous Limits a second time will return the graph back to the most recent changes.

Url.Title: Full Scale Axis
Url.Abstract: Full Scale Axis The Full Scale Axis option redraws the selected axis as it first appeared when you generated it from the data file. The graph is autoscaled to the minimum and maximum data values for the selected axis only.

Url.Title: Full Scale All
Url.Abstract: Full Scale All The Full Scale All option redraws the graph as it first appeared when you generated it from the data file. The graph is autoscaled to the minimum and maximum data values for all of the axes contained in the file.

Url.Title: Common Scale
Url.Abstract: Common Scale When the Common Scale option is selected, all of the axes that have the same Y-axis signal units are autoscaled to match the widest axis. All of the curves on the axes with the same units are then adjusted to have the same data range, and are displayed in full view on the graph.

Url.Title: Stack Axes
Url.Abstract: Stack Axes When you select Stack Axes, the y-axes are adjusted so that the curves on the axes are stacked, one above the other, with no curves from one axis overlapping the curves of another axis. Click here for an example.

Url.Title: Exact Scaling X Menu
Url.Abstract: Exact Scaling X Menu Click on this menu item to check the Exact Scaling X-Axis option. Check this option to have the axis plotted using the exact range of the x-coordinates found in the data file or rescale zoom box.

Url.Title: Exact Scaling Y Menu
Url.Abstract: Exact Scaling Y Menu Click on this menu item to check the Exact Scaling Y-Axis option. Check this option to have the axis plotted using the exact range of the y-coordinates found in the data file or rescale zoom box.

Url.Title: Graph Menu
Url.Abstract: Graph Menu Use the Graph menu to select options that allow you to set up your graphs, either before or after analysis by changing signals, units, parameters, data limits, etc.

Url.Title: About Data File Character Sets
Url.Abstract: About Data File Character Sets A character set is a group of symbols and printing controls that are represented by numeric codes. This is distinguished from a font, which is the graphic rendering of the symbols in a character set.

Url.Title: Spreadsheet View
Url.Abstract: Spreadsheet View Use this function to toggle between the spreadsheet view and the graph view. When you display the data in spreadsheet view some menus will change and some menu items will be unavailable.

Url.Title: Signal Selection Window
Url.Abstract: Signal Selection Window You can use the Signal Selection window to choose the signal and type for the X and Y axes. These signals will be plotted on the graph for the data file to be used for analysis.

Url.Title: Units Selection Window
Url.Abstract: Units Selection Window The Units Selection window is used to change the units used for the selected signals. This window displays the units most commonly used during analysis. To select units, follow these steps:

Url.Title: Moving Labels
Url.Abstract: Moving Labels To reposition a label, use the drag-and-drop method. Position the pointer over the label and hold down the left mouse button while you drag the label to the desired position. When you move the text, the callout arrow (if selected) will automatically reposition itself.

Url.Title: Instrument Parameters
Url.Abstract: Instrument Parameters Use the Instrument Parameters option to access the Instrument Parameters window, which enables you to edit instrument parameters that affect the data.

Url.Title: Parameters Same As
Url.Abstract: Parameters Same As Use the Params Same As option to copy the parameters used in another file to the current file. The parameters that are copied include the signals and units selected, graph options, baseline file (if applicable), and smoothing.

Url.Title: Data Limits
Url.Abstract: Data Limits Use the Data Limits option to select from four options: Full Range, Cursor, Time, Temperature, or Cycle. These allow you to use the entire data file for analysis, or to place constraints on the amount and type of data.

Url.Title: Refresh
Url.Abstract: Refresh Use the Refresh option to redraw the graph using the current data points. See also:

Url.Title: X Axis
Url.Abstract: X Axis Use the X-Axis option to select the signal to graph on the X axis. Click on the name of the signal and the graph will be replotted immediately.

Url.Title: Y Axis
Url.Abstract: Y Axis Use the Y Axis option to select a Y-axis signal for functions such as rescaling, analysis, etc. Emphasis will be switched to that signal (as seen by the small box enclosing the Y-axis number). This option is only available when multiple Y-axis signals are displayed.

Url.Title: Curve
Url.Abstract: Curve Use the Curve option to switch between different curves on the selected axis of an overlay graph, so that you can perform functions on that curve (such as rescaling, analysis, etc.).

Url.Title: Plot Full Range Menu
Url.Abstract: Plot Full Range Menu Click on Plot Full Range to check this option. This option is used to have the data that falls outside of the analysis range plotted, but grayed out. Data outside the analysis range is plotted in the "Plot Grid" color. This is the default setting.

Url.Title: Auto Scale New Data X Menu
Url.Abstract: Auto Scale New Data X Menu Click on Autoscale New Data X to select this function. When checked the current files x-axis data will be autoscaled when the program reads in new data for Graph/Data Limits, Tools/Linear Transform, or a new Graph/X axis. This is the default setting.

Url.Title: Auto Scale New Data Y Menu
Url.Abstract: Auto Scale New Data Y Menu Click on Autoscale New Data Y to select this function. When checked the current files y-axis data will be autoscaled when the program reads in new data for Graph/Data Limits, Tools/Linear Transform, or a new Graph/Y axis. This is the default setting.

Url.Title: Ignore Breaks in Data Menu
Url.Abstract: Ignore Breaks in Data Menu Click on Ignore Breaks in Data to check this function, which is used to have the current data file plotted with a continuous curve, regardless of any breaks in the data points. The data will be interpolated to create an unbroken curve.

Url.Title: Using Symbols
Url.Abstract: Using Symbols Symbols are a fun way to creatively represent your information on the graphs. You can use symbols to differentiate between axes or curves.

Url.Title: Plot Header Window
Url.Abstract: Plot Header Window Use the Plot Header window to set up a customized header that will be placed on the top of an exported or printed graph. Follow the steps below to configure the header.

Url.Title: Plot Legend Window
Url.Abstract: Plot Legend Window Use the Plot Legend window to set up a customized legend that will be placed on the graph. Follow the steps below to configure the legend.

Url.Title: Inset View
Url.Abstract: Inset View Use this function to add a picture-in-picture window to the plot. When you select this option, the Inset View dialog is displayed to allow you to customize the insert view.

Url.Title: Graph Options Window
Url.Abstract: Graph Options Window Use the Graph Options window to choose the graph settings that will apply to the file currently displayed. When you want to set up the appearance of your graph, follow these steps:

Url.Title: How to Set Thicker Line Types
Url.Abstract: How to Set Thicker Line Types NOTE: Changes in line thickness and font size do not show up on the screen plot. You must use print preview to see changes in text size. Changes in line thickness will only show up on the printer itself.

Url.Title: Overlay
Url.Abstract: Overlay Performing a curve overlay operation lets you combine curves from several different experiments or experimental techniques to provide a visual comparison of the data. This will allow you to "overlay" the curves on one window and position the graphs to display the data in a manner that enables you to emphasize important aspects of the data. Up to four individual y-axes may be used, containing up to ten curves, each of common units.

Url.Title: Reordering Curves
Url.Abstract: Reordering Curves You can reorder the sequence of overlay curves on a selected axis from the Curve Overlay Options  Curves Page as follows:

Url.Title: Auto Configure (Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Auto Configure (Overlay) Performing a curve overlay operation lets you combine curves from several different experiments or experimental techniques to provide a visual comparison of the data. This will allow you to "overlay" the curves on one window and position the graphs to display the data in a manner that enables you to emphasize important aspects of the data. Up to four individual y-axes may be used, containing up to ten curves, each of common units. You can create up to 20 different curve overlay plots using the program.

Url.Title: Manual Set Up (Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Manual Set Up (Overlay) Performing a curve overlay operation lets you combine curves from several different experiments or experimental techniques to provide a visual comparison of the data. This will allow you to "overlay" the curves on one window and position the graphs to display the data in a manner that enables you to emphasize important aspects of the data. Up to four individual y-axes may be used, containing up to ten curves, each of common units. You can create a total of 20 different overlay plot windows.

Url.Title: Selecting an Overlay Curve
Url.Abstract: Selecting an Overlay Curve To perform functions on a curve contained in a curve overlay window, follow the instructions below:

Url.Title: Edit Overlay Plot (Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Edit Overlay Plot (Overlay) Use the Edit option to edit the current curve overlay plot. When you select this menu option, you are presented with a choice of overlay plots to copy. When you select the desired plot, the Curve Overlay Options window is displayed, which allows you to make changes to the current curve overlay.

Url.Title: Overlay Legend Size
Url.Abstract: Overlay Legend Size The curve overlay legend is a block of information that can be used to identify the curves used on your curve overlay graph. Because there are many options that you can select or set up to appear on this legend, it may get too large. You may not detect that the legend is too large on your display since font size changes do not appear on the display screen, but will appear when the plot is printed.

Url.Title: Analyze Menu
Url.Abstract: Analyze Menu Use the Analyze menu to choose the type of analysis that you want to perform on the current data file. This menu reflects the type of analyses available for the particular type of data file that is currently active. For example, if a DSC data file is currently active, the Analyze menu contains only those types of analyses that relate to DSC files.

Url.Title: Analyze Pop-Up Menu
Url.Abstract: Analyze Pop-Up Menu Use this pop-up menu to change to a manual method for entering data limits, accept the limits chosen, cancel the operation, or choose a point to enter.

Url.Title: Analyze Purity
Url.Abstract: Analyze Purity  Before analyzing the data, set up the analysis options by selecting Analyze/Purity/Options.

Url.Title: Alpha At X
Url.Abstract: Alpha At X Use the Alpha at X option to calculate the expansion coefficient (alpha) using a single point on a TMA curve. Alpha is calculated from the smoothed digital derivative at the point.

Url.Title: Alpha Fit X1 to X2
Url.Abstract: Alpha Fit X1 to X2 Use the Alpha Fit X1 to X2 option to calculate an expansion coefficient that is measured as the slope of a line fit through a region of data between two points on a TMA curve.

Url.Title: Alpha X1 to X2
Url.Abstract: Alpha X1 to X2 Use the Alpha X1 to X2 option to calculate the expansion coefficient changes in dimension, divided by the change in temperature between two selected points on a TMA curve.

Url.Title: Analysis Range
Url.Abstract: Analysis Range Use the Analysis Range option to set the analysis range from portions of the original X-axis range, thus confining your data for analysis purposes to the chosen range. Data outside this range becomes invisible to the analysis functions, but analyses already performed on these curves are retained.

Url.Title: Curve Value At X
Url.Abstract: Curve Value At X Use the Curve Value At X analysis option to determine the axis value(s) at the selected X-axis point on the curve. Marking the curve with this feature allows you to label a curve at any point.

Url.Title: Curve Value At Y
Url.Abstract: Curve Value At Y Use the Curve Value At Y analysis option to determine the axis value(s) at the selected Y-axis point on the curve. If more than one point is encountered by the marker, the first point is used. Marking the curve with this feature allows you to label a curve at any point.

Url.Title: Dimension Change
Url.Abstract: Dimension Change During your TMA experiment, the sample will react to the changes in the physical environment placed upon it. This may be a change in temperature, force, or atmosphere. The resulting dimension change of the TMA sample is detected by the instruments probe and can be measured between any two points on the data curve using the Dimension Change option.

Url.Title: Full Range
Url.Abstract: Full Range Use the Full Range menu option to restore all of the data points available in the file for analysis after the range has been limited by one of the other analysis range options.

Url.Title: Glass Transition
Url.Abstract: Glass Transition Use the Glass Transition menu item to calculate the onset, end, inflection, and signal change of a glass transition in the curve. For example, this analysis enables you to determine the glass transition by DSC.

Url.Title: Integrate Peak
Url.Abstract: Integrate Peak Use the Integrate Peak options to calculate and report the following: · Start and stop temperatures

Url.Title: Label At X,Y
Url.Abstract: Label At X,Y Use the Label At X,Y analysis option to determine the X and Y coordinates for any point within the graph limits, even if it is not on the curve. (To determine points on a curve, use the Analyze/Curve Value at X or Curve Value at Y options.)

Url.Title: Macros (Analyze Menu)
Url.Abstract: Macros (Analyze Menu) Use this menu option to open a macro from the list displayed. Macros are used to perform Autoanalysis (automatic analysis) of data files.

Url.Title: Modify Size
Url.Abstract: Modify Size Use the Modify Size options for TGA files to modify the sample weight used in the percent weight calculations. This allows you to provide volatile-free and ash-free results. These options can also be used to isolate a reaction from other side reactions (e.g., oxidation).

Url.Title: Reset Size
Url.Abstract: Reset Size Use the Analyze/Reset Size option for TGA and TMA files to modify the sample size used for the calculations. This allows you to compensate for changes in sample size due to sample conditioning (e.g., volatilization, adsorption, relaxation, curing, etc.).

Url.Title: Onset Point
Url.Abstract: Onset Point Use the Onset Point analysis option to determine the temperature at which a change in the slope of the curve occurs (i.e., the onset point of a transition). The onset point is defined as the intersection of an initial tangent line with a final tangent line.

Url.Title: Options (Analyze)
Url.Abstract: Options (Analyze) Use the Options menu item found in the Analyze menu to set up parameters that will be used when analyzing your data files.

Url.Title: Oxidation Time/Temp
Url.Abstract: Oxidation Time/Temp Use the Oxidation Time/Temp option to analyze DSC data from oxidation induction time (OIT) and oxidation temperature (OT) experiments.

Url.Title: Peak Max
Url.Abstract: Peak Max Use the Peak Max option to calculate a peaks point of maximum deviation from a linear baseline drawn between two points on the curve. After you select the start and stop limits for the baseline, the program calculates and reports the height of the peak.

Url.Title: Residue
Url.Abstract: Residue Use the Residue option to report the difference between any selected point on the TGA curve and the final weight. The final weight is assumed to be zero, but can be modified to any value using the Modify Size option.

Url.Title: Running Integral
Url.Abstract: Running Integral Use the Running Integral option when you want to determine the area under a peak or the ratio of different materials within a sample. For example, in TGA, this function is valuable for determining the relative amounts of evolved gases in a material. In DSC, it can be used to calculate the percent composition of polymer blends.

Url.Title: Signal Change
Url.Abstract: Signal Change Use the Signal Change option to determine the amount of change in the signal between two points on a curve. A horizontal line is drawn from your selected start point to a vertical line drawn from your selected stop point. The difference between these points is reported.

Url.Title: Signal Max
Url.Abstract: Signal Max Use the Signal Max option to calculate the maximum signal value between two selected points.

Url.Title: Slope
Url.Abstract: Slope Use the Slope option to calculate the average slope of a selected region of the curve. Follow these steps for perform this analysis:

Url.Title: Step Transition
Url.Abstract: Step Transition Use the Step Transition menu item to calculate the onset, end, inflection, and signal change of a step transition in the curve. For example, this analysis enables you to determine decomposition temperatures by TGA.

Url.Title: Temp/Time at Weight %
Url.Abstract: Temp/Time at Weight % Use the Temp/Time at Weight % option to locate the X-axis value on a TGA curve (either time or temperature) that corresponds to a selected Y-axis value, and label the graph with the weight percent.

Url.Title: Weight Change
Url.Abstract: Weight Change Use the Weight Change option to determine the amount of change in the weight between two points on a TGA curve. A horizontal line is drawn from your selected start point to a vertical line drawn from your selected stop point. The difference between these points is reported in the units of the Y-axis.

Url.Title: Weight At Temp/Time
Url.Abstract: Weight At Temp/Time Use the Weight At Temp/Time option to locate the X-axis value on a TGA curve (either time or temperature) that corresponds to a selected Y-axis value, and label the graph with the weight remaining in the sample.

Url.Title: Weight Loss Temp/Time
Url.Abstract: Weight Loss Temp/Time Use the Weight Loss Temp/Time option to locate the X-axis value on a TGA curve (either temperature or time respectively) that corresponds to a selected Y-axis value, and label the graph with the weight lost (µg, mg, or %) from the sample (from the original or 100% weight).

Url.Title: What is the Derivative Fraction?
Url.Abstract: What is the Derivative Fraction? Derivation fraction is a percentage of the derivative curve. It is used when performing a TGA Weight Change or Signal Change analysis as follows: The program will first determine the highest derivative peak in the current data file. Then the program will go down the highest peak until it determines where the desired fraction of that derivative peak is reached. Then it will find the middle of the area between the two derivative peaks at that fraction point and use that as the analysis point. For example, if you use the default derivative fraction of 0.05, the program scans down the highest derivative peak until it comes to the 5 percent point of that peak. Then the middle of the area between the highest peak and the one next to it is determined and used at the analysis limit (either Point 1 or Point 2, or both).

Url.Title: Derivative Calculation
Url.Abstract: Derivative Calculation Although the derivative of a mathematical curve can be determined exactly, the derivative of a curve of data points is always an estimation or average of the slopes of lines between points.

Url.Title: Difference Between Signal Max and Peak Max
Url.Abstract: Difference Between Signal Max and Peak Max Signal Max and Peak Max (Peak Integration Height) appear to report the same analysis result, but they are actually different analyses. The result provided by each is highly dependant on the baseline selected.

Url.Title: Performing MDSC® Phase Correction
Url.Abstract: Performing MDSC® Phase Correction Modulated DSC (MDSC®) analysis has generally been used to measure the heat capacity (Cp) of a material. However, the MDSC technique can also be used to calculate phase-lag and its contribution to the measured heat capacity signal. The Thermal Advantage Universal Analysis program contains algorithms that allow you to calculate the Reversing Heat Capacity and Nonreversing Heat Capacity signals, as well as the phase corrected Reversing Heat Flow and Nonreversing Heat Flow signals. Total heat flow is not affected by deviations in the heat flow phase. MDSC phase correction can be done using the automatic calculations as follows:

Url.Title: Obtaining a Peak Endset
Url.Abstract: Obtaining a Peak Endset (Backside Onset) There are two approaches to obtaining a peak endset (onset analysis on the backside of a peak).

Url.Title: Collecting DSC Purity Data
Url.Abstract: Collecting DSC Purity Data You can analyze DSC data from many types of samples using DSC Purity analysis.

Url.Title: Purity Basic Steps
Url.Abstract: Purity Basic Steps Follow these basic steps when performing a DSC Purity analysis: 1. Collect your data.

Url.Title: Purity Analysis
Url.Abstract: Purity Analysis The TA Instruments DSC Purity Analysis can be used to calculate the absolute purity of a sample based on data obtained from the DSC (Differential Scanning Calorimeter) according to ASTM procedure E0928.*

Url.Title: Purity Options
Url.Abstract: Purity Options Use the Analyze/Purity/Options function to set up the options available for DSC purity analysis.

Url.Title: Humidity Basic Steps
Url.Abstract: Humidity Basic Steps Follow these basic steps when performing a TGA Humidity analysis: 1. Collect your data following the guidelines suggested. See Humidity Analysis.

Url.Title: Humidity Mark Adsorption/Desorption
Url.Abstract: Humidity Mark Adsorption/Desorption Use the Analyze/Humidity/Mark Adsorption and Analyze/Humidity/Mark Desorption functions to manually specify the beginning of each humidity isotherm on the curve. This is useful when the automatic determination of rising and falling weight does not coincide with programmed humidity levels, or when the sample is conditioned (e.g., by drying or saturation) prior to the start of the experiment.

Url.Title: Humidity Analysis
Url.Abstract: Humidity Analysis The TA Instruments Humidity Analysis can be used to calculate the humidity composition of a sample based on data obtained from the Q5000 SA.

Url.Title: Humidity Analysis Options
Url.Abstract: Humidity Analysis Options Use the Analyze/Humidity/Options function to set up the options available for TGA humidity analysis.

Url.Title: Analyze Humidity BET Analysis
Url.Abstract: Analyze Humidity BET Analysis Select this item to fit the sorption isotherm data from the Q5000 SA to the BET model.

Url.Title: Analyze Humidity GAB Analysis
Url.Abstract: Analyze Humidity GAB Analysis Select this item to fit the sorption isotherm data from the Q5000SA to the GAB model.

Url.Title: Analyze Humidity Sorption Isotherm
Url.Abstract: Analyze Humidity Sorption Isotherm Select this item to plot the Humidity Sorption Isotherm of the current data file.

Url.Title: Tools Menu
Url.Abstract: Tools Menu Use the Tools menu to select from a list of different types of functions that can performed on the current graph. You can smooth, shift, and/or rotate the curve and perform a linear transformation on either axis. If you change your mind you can remove the curve shifts.

Url.Title: Curve Shift and Curve Rotation Calculations
Url.Abstract: Curve Shift and Curve Rotation Calculations The process of curve shifting and curve rotation causes a linear change to a curve's baseline. Curve shifting moves all of the data points on a curve up or down by a fixed value. Curve rotation moves the data points on a curve up or down by a linearly changing value.

Url.Title: View Menu
Url.Abstract: View Menu Use the View menu to choose from an assortment of information on the analysis to view, and in some cases, edit or print.

Url.Title: Spreadsheet (View in Excel)
Url.Abstract: Spreadsheet (View in Excel) Use this function to open the Microsoft Excel® program with a blank first sheet.

Url.Title: Creating a TMA Table of Alpha
Url.Abstract: Creating a TMA Table of Alpha To produce an alpha curve and a table of alpha using TMA data files, follow these steps:

Url.Title: Analysis Log
Url.Abstract: Analysis Log View/Analysis Log allows you to view all of the steps used to manipulate and view the data for each open data file. The analysis log captures these steps and allows you to view and print them. You can also convert the analysis log to a program macro using the Macros/Copy/Analysis Log menu item.

Url.Title: Audit Trail
Url.Abstract: Audit Trail The TA Instruments Integrity system provides secure, computer-generated, time-stamped audit trails to independently record events. Each record identifies the person, time/date, and a description of the event. Comments may be added, if desired, by the user.

Url.Title: Using the Report Editor Program
Url.Abstract: Using the Report Editor Program The Report Editor is a text editor program that is contained within the TA Instruments Universal Analysis program. It functions very much like other simple text editors that you may have used.

Url.Title: File Menu (Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: File Menu (Report Editor) Use the File menu to open a text file and perform various functions such as closing any open files, saving and printing files, etc.

Url.Title: Save (Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Save (Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Save option to save the current text file. The default text file format is Rich Text Format (.rtf). Use Rich Text Format to save the font, text, size, etc. Use ordinary test format (.txt) to save only the text characters and not the format information. Always use ordinary text format (.txt) to save ASCII or spread sheet data files.

Url.Title: Edit Menu (Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: Edit Menu (Report Editor) Use the Edit menu to perform various editing functions on the current graph.

Url.Title: Insert Menu (Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: Insert Menu (Report Editor) Use the Insert menu to add the items shown in the menu (add listed below) to your text file. This can allow you to create one file that contains all of the information gathered from the current data file.

Url.Title: Help Menu (Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: Help Menu (Report Editor) Use the Help menu to access help topics and help on the Report Editor. See also:

Url.Title: Using the Custom Report Editor Program
Url.Abstract: Using the Custom Report Editor Program The Custom Report Editor is used to create and edit customized Universal Analysis report templates. The templates are created using any number of report objects such as plots, results, parameters, method log, data tables, etc. The report object boxes (which represent the plots, results, etc.) can be sized and positioned as desired to fit on a single piece of paper. After a template file is created and saved, it can be used over and over again with different data files and can even be linked to an Autoanalysis macro to further automate the process of analysis and report generation.

Url.Title: Options (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Options (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use this menu item to access the Custom Report Options window that allows you to select settings for the program. The types of options available are: set up for the object box, format of the editor grid, units used in the printed report, number of report copies, and various spreadsheet options.

Url.Title: File Menu (Custom Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: File Menu (Custom Report Editor) Use the File menu to open a template file and perform various functions such as closing any open files, setting up options, saving and printing files, etc.

Url.Title: Edit Menu (Custom Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: Edit Menu (Custom Report Editor) Use the Edit menu to make changes to an existing report template. You can cut, copy, paste, delete, and select all report objects; you can make changes to specific characteristics of a report object; and you can make the objects snap to the grid or lock their position.

Url.Title: Insert Menu (Custom Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: Insert Menu (Custom Report Editor) Use the Insert menu (or the buttons on the tool bar) in the Custom Report Editor program to insert a variety of report objects into a custom report template. You can then resize, move, and format the objects as desired and save them to a template file.

Url.Title: Help Menu (Custom Report Editor)
Url.Abstract: Help Menu (Custom Report Editor) Use the Help menu to access the Universal Analysis general help topics and help topics that apply to the Custom Report Editor program.

Url.Title: Uses for Macros
Url.Abstract: Uses for Macros Macros can be very useful tools if you find yourself performing a set of steps (including analysis) more than once. A macro can contain a few very basic steps or it could contain a very complex (normally time-consuming) set of instructions. Here are some examples:

Url.Title: Tips on Capturing Macros
Url.Abstract: Tips on Capturing Macros The successful completion of a macro, from beginning to end, depends on a continuous selection of steps that have a logical fit. Errors can arise due to changes in the state of the program. Listed below are some hints to help you produce a successful macro.

Url.Title: Using the Macro Editor
Url.Abstract: Using the Macro Editor Select Macro Editor from the Macros menu to display the Macro Editor window for the current macro. This window displays a list of all of the steps contained in the macro as they are captured and provides valuable information when you capture, view, edit, and debug the macro steps.

Url.Title: Macros Menu
Url.Abstract: Macros Menu Use the Macro menu to choose a function to perform relating to the use of macros to perform data analysis automatically.

Url.Title: Macro Menu
Url.Abstract: Macro Editor Menu Use the Macro Editor menu to choose a function to perform relating to the use of macros to perform data analysis automatically.

Url.Title: Macro Edit Menu
Url.Abstract: Macro Edit Menu Use the Edit menu to make changes to an already-captured macro. Select the menu item from the drop-down Edit menu to make the desired changes.

Url.Title: Macro Insert Menu
Url.Abstract: Macro Insert Menu Use the Insert menu to add dialogs (message boxes), pauses (delays), jumps to other steps, beeps, and other functions that can be used to further customize the steps in your macro. Select the desired position for the insert option before selecting the menu item from the drop-down Insert menu.

Url.Title: What is a Macro Variable?
Url.Abstract: What is a Macro Variable? Macro variables provide the ability to store, manipulate, and test numbers inside an executing macro. Each variable can store a single floating-point number or an array of numbers. Up to 200 macro variables and/or array elements can be defined at one time. Three macro steps (Assign Variable, Assign Clipboard, and Test Variable) in the Insert menu of the macro editor provide access to the user defined variables.

Url.Title: Predefined Program Variables
Url.Abstract: Predefined Program Variables Direct access to a number of program variables is available through the macro system. Program variables are predefined when a macro runs and do not require initialization (see definitions below). A program variable can be used in exactly the same way as a user defined variable except that the value of the variable is read or written directly from the current open data file in the program.

Url.Title: Macro Help Menu
Url.Abstract: Macro Help Menu Use the Macro Editor Help menu to access macro help information. See also:

Url.Title: Introduction to Autoanalysis
Url.Abstract: Introduction to Autoanalysis Autoanalysis is an option for the Universal Analysis program that is designed to streamline the data analysis process. Using Autoanalysis you can automatically retrieve the data files from completed experiments and perform a predetermined analysis without operator intervention (this is called Autoqueuing). When used in this fashion, Autoanalysis provides increased productivity, particularly when combined with a DSC or TGA autosampler.

Url.Title: What is an Autoqueue?
Url.Abstract: What is an Autoqueue? Autoanalyzing is the process where one or more multiple analysis records (containing the data filename, macro filename, and applicable macro) are added to an autoqueue and automatically processed. Analysis records may be added to the autoqueue either from the controller or manually through Universal Analysis (use Macro/Autoqueue menu).

Url.Title: How is an Autoqueue Made?
Url.Abstract: How is an Autoqueue Made? The first thing you need to do is to open the Universal Analysis program to create the macro that will be used to analyze your data files. For this macro to work successfully, it must start with an "Open File" step (File/Open). When you create the macro you should use a file similar to the type to be autoanalyzed (e.g., DSC, MDSC, TGA, etc.). Later, when the experiment is complete, the autoanalysis record (containing the finished data filenames) will be appended to the autoqueue. (NOTE: No spaces can be used in the directory or file names.)

Url.Title: Autoqueue File Menu
Url.Abstract: Autoqueue File Menu Use the File menu to perform various functions such as running or printing an autoqueue, importing records from an exported file into the autoqueue, and exporting an autoqueue.

Url.Title: Autoqueue Edit Menu
Url.Abstract: Autoqueue Edit Menu Use the Edit menu to make changes to an autoqueue. This menu allows you to reorder the autoanalysis records (cut/paste), remove records (cut or delete), add records (append) or change existing records (modify). Select the menu item from the drop-down Edit menu to make the desired changes.

Url.Title: Window Menu
Url.Abstract: Window Menu Use the Windows menu to arrange the currently open windows in different configurations. See also:

Url.Title: Help Topics
Url.Abstract: Help Topics Use this menu item to display the topics available in the online help associated with the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: User Manual
Url.Abstract: User Manual Use this menu item to display the online manual for Universal Analysis.

Url.Title: How To?
Url.Abstract: How To? Use this menu item to display a list of frequently asked questions that link to step-by-step instructions on how to perform certain functions in the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Glossary
Url.Abstract: Glossary Use this menu item to display the TA Instruments online glossary of thermal analysis terms.

Url.Title: About Universal Analysis
Url.Abstract: About Universal Analysis Use this command to display the copyright notice, software key information, version number, and license information for your copy of Thermal AdvantageUniversal Analysis.

Url.Title: Abort Autoqueue Changes?
Url.Abstract: Abort Autoqueue Changes? Problem: The system has detected the fact that the autoqueue file was manually modified since the last time it was updated by Instrument Control. If you decide to save the manual modification, any new records that were appended in the meantime by Instrument Control will be lost.

Url.Title: Abort File Read
Url.Abstract: Abort File Read You have pressed the Escape key to abort reading the data file. Do you want to stop the data input into the program?

Url.Title: Add More File Information?
Url.Abstract: Add More File Information? Do you want to add temperature, weight, and parameter information from a currently open data file?

Url.Title: Annotation is Too Big
Url.Abstract: Annotation is Too Big Problem: The size of your annotation text block is too large. Solution: Do not enter more than 620 characters (including spaces) in an annotation.

Url.Title: Autoqueue Almost Full
Url.Abstract: Autoqueue Almost Full The autoqueue is filled to more than 90 percent of its capacity. It is recommended that you process (autoanalyze) or remove some of the autoqueue records to avoid overflow of the autoqueue and subsequent loss of new records.

Url.Title: Bad Data File
Url.Abstract: Bad Data File The data format version information in this file is missing or corrupted. Reading this file may cause program errors. Verify that this file is a valid data file. Do you want to continue reading this file?

Url.Title: Bad Data Format Version
Url.Abstract: Bad Data Format Version Data format version information is missing or invalid.

Url.Title: Bad Data in File
Url.Abstract: Bad Data in File Invalid data in file. Cannot continue reading. Problem: The analysis program was not able to skip a section of damaged data values that were detected in the data file. The data up to this point will be displayed.

Url.Title: Bad Data Point
Url.Abstract: Bad Data Point The analysis program has detected a section of damaged data values. If you open this file, the bad data points that were detected will be skipped.

Url.Title: Bad Initialization File
Url.Abstract: Bad Initialization File The initialization file is corrupted and is not usable. Either use a different initialization file or create and save a new one.

Url.Title: Bad Intersection
Url.Abstract: Bad Intersection Onset or end not within limits. Problem: The onset or end tangent lines did not intersect within your selected transition start and stop limits.

Url.Title: Bad Macro File
Url.Abstract: Bad Macro File Problem: There is a problem with the macro file that you are attempting to open. The file could be corrupted or it may have been created with a different program. It cannot be used.

Url.Title: Bad Midpoint
Url.Abstract: Bad Midpoint Problem: The tangent lines in a step transition midpoint calculation (using the half-extrapolated tangents option) fall outside your selected step transition limits.

Url.Title: Bad Parameter Block
Url.Abstract: Bad Parameter Block The parameter block information in this file is invalid or corrupted. Reading this file may cause program errors. Do you want to continue reading this file?

Url.Title: Bad Session File
Url.Abstract: Bad Session File Problem: You have attempted to load a session file from a previous version of the Universal Analysis program (the DOS UA program). It is not compatible with the new software.

Url.Title: Cancel Login?
Url.Abstract: Cancel Login? Problem: This message is displayed when a login function is canceled in a 21 CFR 11 Universal Analysis session that has had inactivity for a defined period of time, or when you log out of a 21 CFR 11 Universal Analysis session and one or more data files are still open.

Url.Title: Cannot Access Autoqueue
Url.Abstract: Cannot Access Autoqueue Cannot access system autoqueue file. Problem: The program looks for the autoqueue file in a certain directory. If the program cannot find the file, or if the file has been renamed, then the program cannot access the autoqueue.

Url.Title: Cannot Change Buffer Size
Url.Abstract: Cannot Change Buffer Size Problem: The data buffer size cannot be changed while files are already open.

Url.Title: Cannot Change Cell Constant
Url.Abstract: Cannot Change Cell Constant Problem: The Edit Parameter Block function is designed to permit virtually any change to a data file parameter block with the understanding that this function makes an exact copy of the current data file withoutchanging the data in any way. See also: Edit Parameter Block window

Url.Title: Cannot Change Selected Value
Url.Abstract: Cannot Change Selected Value This message is displayed if you try to change a value in the Spreadsheet View of the data (Graph/Spreadsheet View) that cannot be changed. For example, the multiplexed frequency or cycle number associated with a data point cannot be changed.

Url.Title: Cannot Convert Data File
Url.Abstract: Cannot Convert Data File This message is displayed if you try to open a Perkin Elmer DDSC modulated temperature data file using Universal Analysis. This type of file cannot be converted and opened by the program.

Url.Title: Cannot Correct Geometry
Url.Abstract: Cannot Correct Geometry Problem: When analyzing DMA data files, if a new value is entered for sample size or Poissons ratio, then the sample size must be recalculated. If there is no original sample geometry in the data file, if the sample size is entered as zero, or if the sample geometry is unsupported, then this message will occur.

Url.Title: Cannot Correct Peak Area
Url.Abstract: Cannot Correct Peak Area This message is displayed in the following two cases:  If a peak on the signal "Wt corrected heat flow" is integrated with any weight option other than "Original" weight.

Url.Title: Cannot Create PDF File
Url.Abstract: Cannot Create PDF File PDFlib processor error. Cannot create PDF file. Problem: This message is displayed if an error occurs during PDF file creation using Universal Analysis. The most common cause of the problem is a missing or unregistered dynamic link library file called pdflib_com.dll or pdflib_com_5.dll.

Url.Title: Cannot Edit Macro Step
Url.Abstract: Cannot Edit Macro Step Cannot edit this macro step. The macro step selected in the Macro Edit window cannot be modified. You can edit steps that contain a text entry, insert parameter, cursor or mouse coordinate, checkbox or radio button selection, or color selection. You cannot, for instance, change a button selection.

Url.Title: Cannot Find Autoqueue Target
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Autoqueue Target Problem: Each record in the autoqueue contains a specific data file, macro file, and a macro. When the autoqueue is processed (autoanalyzed), the program must be able to find each one of these components. If this error occurs, the program cannot locate one of the components of a record contained in the autoqueue.

Url.Title: Cannot Find Cycle Data
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Cycle Data This message is displayed when you attempt to open a Mass Spectrometer file in Universal Analysis and the program cannot locate or read the cycle data. The cycle data that the program is attempting to read starts on the next line after the line with the header "Cycle Date Time RelTime[s]."

Url.Title: Cannot Find File
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find File Problem: This message can occur in the following circumstances: Solution:

Url.Title: Cannot Find Function for Macro Step
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Function for Macro Step

Url.Title: Cannot Find Hit Label
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Hit Label

Url.Title: Cannot Find Intersection
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Intersection

Url.Title: Cannot Find Label in Macro
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Label in Macro

Url.Title: Cannot Find Macro
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Macro Cannot find macro <macro name>.

Url.Title: Cannot Find Multiplex Signal
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Multiplex Signal Problem: The "Multiplex" parameter, in the data files parameter block, specifies the name of a multiplexed signal that was not found in the data file.

Url.Title: Cannot Find Number on Clipboard
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Number on Clipboard

Url.Title: Cannot Find Signal
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Signal Problem: A required signal is missing from the primary data file or from a temporary work file. The selected analysis cannot be performed.

Url.Title: Cannot Find Text on Clipboard
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Text on Clipboard

Url.Title: Cannot Find the Target for Macro Step
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find the Target for Macro Step Cannot find target for macro step.

Url.Title: Cannot Find the Window for Macro Step
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find the Window for Macro Step

Url.Title: Cannot Find Valid Data
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Valid Data

Url.Title: Cannot Find Weight
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Weight

Url.Title: Cannot Fit Log Axes
Url.Abstract: Cannot Fit Log Axes Problem: The entire data file cannot be plotted using log axes. Solution: Try one of the following:

Url.Title: Cannot Fit To Data
Url.Abstract: Cannot Fit To Data Problem: The curve cannot be fit to the adjacent data using the data limits and the Exclude Data option that you selected.

Url.Title: Cannot Get Record ID
Url.Abstract: Cannot Get Record ID Problem: An error occurred while attempting to obtain a new record ID to store information in the database. The information is not stored.

Url.Title: Cannot Import Macro
Url.Abstract: Cannot Import Macro

Url.Title: Cannot Log In
Url.Abstract: Cannot Log In Problem: You have open files in Universal Analysis that are not part of the 21 CFR 11 database and cannot log in with them open. You cannot mix data files from the database with those that are not part of the database.

Url.Title: Cannot Mix Signals
Url.Abstract: Cannot Mix Signals Problem: You attempted to mix multiplexed signals from a data file and a plot in a new output file. When multiplexed signals are plotted, they are sorted and arranged in a special data format that is not compatible with the original data file.

Url.Title: Cannot Overwrite File
Url.Abstract: Cannot Overwrite File Problem: You attempted to write a new data file that has the same filename as one of the open files in the analysis program.

Url.Title: Cannot Paste Record. Autoqueue Full.
Url.Abstract: Cannot Paste Record. Autoqueue Full. Problem: You need to process (autoanalyze) the autoqueue. It has been accumulating records and has now reached at least 90 percent capacity. There is not enough room to paste in another record. If the records are not processed and removed from the autoqueue to allow more space, incoming records will not be appended and will be lost.

Url.Title: Cannot Read Unicode Files
Url.Abstract: Cannot Read Unicode Files Problem: Unicode files cannot be read by this version of Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Cannot Remove Analysis
Url.Abstract: Cannot Remove Analysis

Url.Title: Cannot Remove Offsets
Url.Abstract: Cannot Remove Offsets Problem: The X-axis cursor position from the first curve shift does not provide sufficient information to restore the original curve. The X-axis value of the first point in the curve is equal to that of the last point in the curve, and also to that of the first shift marker.

Url.Title: Cannot Retrieve Record
Url.Abstract: Cannot Retrieve Record Problem: The program was unable to retrieve the record specified in the message for one of the following reasons:

Url.Title: Cannot Retrieve Record Information
Url.Abstract: Cannot Retrieve Record Information Problem: An error occurred while attempting to obtain additional information about a record that is being retrieved from the database. The record retrieval is aborted.

Url.Title: Cannot Save Analysis
Url.Abstract: Cannot Save Analysis Problem: Analysis and set-up information cannot be saved to an ASCII or Spread Sheet format data file.

Url.Title: Cannot Shift
Url.Abstract: Cannot Shift Problem: You are attempting to shift or rotate a curve which has already been shifted or rotated in a different X domain (time or temperature).

Url.Title: Cannot Stack Log Axes
Url.Abstract: Cannot Stack Log Axes Problem: You attempted to use the Stack Axes feature with a log axis. Log axes cannot be stacked automatically.

Url.Title: Cannot Start Excel
Url.Abstract: Cannot Start Excel This message is displayed if you select the View/Spreadsheet option, which is used to open the Microsoft Excel program, but your computer does not have that program installed or it cannot be located. In order to use the View/Spreadsheet option, you must have the Microsoft Excel program installed.

Url.Title: Cannot Start Word
Url.Abstract: Cannot Start Word This message is displayed if you select the View/Custom Report option, but your computer does not have Microsoft Word installed or it cannot be located. The Custom Report Editor program requires that you have Microsoft Word® 97 or Word 2000 installed on your computer.

Url.Title: Cannot Use Norm Units
Url.Abstract: Cannot Use Norm Units Problem: Normalized signal units have been selected for plotting but the sample size is zero.

Url.Title: Cannot Use Sigmoidal Tangents
Url.Abstract: Cannot Use Sigmoidal Tangents Problem: You attempted to perform an Integrate Peak/Sig Tangent analysis on a log axis. Sigmoidal tangents cannot be used on a log axis.

Url.Title: Cannot Use Time
Url.Abstract: Cannot Use Time Problem: You attempted to analyze a curve that has time on the Y-axis. Time cannot be smoothed or analyzed.

Url.Title: Cannot Write Active File
Url.Abstract: Cannot Write Active File Problem: You attempted to write a new data file using a source file that is still being collected, or a file that was opened while data collection was in progress.

Url.Title: Cannot Write to Autoqueue File
Url.Abstract: Cannot Write to Autoqueue File Problem: Open Universal Analysis and try to process the Autoanalysis data manually using the Macros/Autoqueue menu item. If the error persists, you may have a problem with the disk or disk drive.

Url.Title: Check Stop
Url.Abstract: Check Stop This is a program error that may affect your analysis results. Call TA Instruments, if the problem persists.

Url.Title: Close All Files
Url.Abstract: Close All Files This is a confirmation message to ensure that you want to close all of the data files, as directed. Select Cancel to abort this operation and return to the program.

Url.Title: Comment Text Too Long
Url.Abstract: Comment Text Too Long Problem: The maximum length of the comment text for an Audit Trail Comment is 255 characters and you have attempted to add more than what is allowed.

Url.Title: Compaction Failed
Url.Abstract: Compaction Failed The number of data points in this file is too large to store in the current size data buffer, even with automatic data compaction (averaging). You can solve this problem by 1) limiting the range of data read from the data file (see Data Limits), by 2) closing all files and increasing the size of the data buffer (see Main Options/Data page), or by 3) reducing the number of "Data On/Off" or Event" segments in the thermal method and rerunning the experiment.

Url.Title: Confirm Language Removal
Url.Abstract: Confirm Language Removal Select Yes if you want to remove the localization language currently selected in the Other Language List. The corresponding language string file is not deleted. It is simply removed from the list of available languages in the Other Language List and from the Windows registry.

Url.Title: Confirm Macro Deletion
Url.Abstract: Confirm Macro Deletion

Url.Title: Could Not Import Macro(s)
Url.Abstract: Could Not Import Macro(s)

Url.Title: Curve Not Defined
Url.Abstract: Curve Not Defined Problem: You attempted to set new parameters for an overlay curve that is not yet defined.

Url.Title: Data Buffer Too Small
Url.Abstract: Data Buffer Too Small Problem: This message is displayed if you are attempting to restore a saved analysis that requires larger data buffers than the current buffer size was improved to read.

Url.Title: Data Table Size
Url.Abstract: Data Table Size This is an informational message to let you know how many rows the data table will contain at the selected size.

Url.Title: Data Will Not Fit in Buffer
Url.Abstract: Data Will Not Fit in Buffer The multiplexed data from this file will not fit in the data buffer. Some data points will be dropped. To prevent dropping of data, close all open data files and increase the data buffer size to a minimum of xxx points.

Url.Title: Database Login Failed
Url.Abstract: Database Login Failed Problem: An error occurred while attempting to log into the database. The login is aborted.

Url.Title: Database Save Failed
Url.Abstract: Database Save Failed Problem: An error occurred while attempting to save a record in the database. The record is not saved.

Url.Title: Delete All Curves?
Url.Abstract: Delete All Curves? This is a confirmation message to ensure that you want to delete all the curves from all axes on the curve overlay graph. Select Cancel to abort this operation.

Url.Title: Delete All Results
Url.Abstract: Delete All Results? This is a confirmation message to ensure that you want to delete all of the analysis results for the selected plot. Select Cancel to abort this operation.

Url.Title: Delete All Steps?
Url.Abstract: Delete All Steps?

Url.Title: Delete Curve Results
Url.Abstract: Delete Curve Results This is a confirmation message to ensure that you want to delete all of the results on the chosen curve. Select Cancel to abort this operation.

Url.Title: Delete Results?
Url.Abstract: Delete Results? This message is displayed if you have already performed some analysis on a data file, the results are displayed on the curve, and you attempt to change signal units.

Url.Title: Delete to End?
Url.Abstract: Delete to End?

Url.Title: Description Text Too Long
Url.Abstract: Description Text Too Long Description text exceeds maximum length of 255 characters. Problem: The description you have entered in the database Save As window has too much text.

Url.Title: Dialog Already Open
Url.Abstract: Dialog Already Open

Url.Title: Different Names
Url.Abstract: Different Names Problem: This is a curve overlay situation in which the selected files have the same units, but different axis names. This is just a warning message to make sure that you want to produce this curve overlay graph. For example, you can produce a curve overlay graph containing different signals on the same axis, providing that they have the same units (reversing and non-reversing heat flow signals). In these situations you may customize the axis label to reflect curve differences.

Url.Title: Different X Signals
Url.Abstract: Different X Signals Problem: You attempted to create a curve overlay plot that contains files with different X-axis units [e.g., Temperature (°C) in one file and Temperature (°F) in the other], or different X-axis signal types [e.g., Heat Flow (W/g) in one file and Heat Capacity (J/g/°C) in the other], or different X-axis scaling types [e.g., Storage Modulus (MPa) in one file and Log of Storage Modulus (MPa) in the other].

Url.Title: Do You Want to Stop Macro?
Url.Abstract: Do You Want to Stop Macro?

Url.Title: Edit Parameter Block Information
Url.Abstract: Edit Parameter Block Information This function makes an exact copy of the current data file including a new user-modified parameter block. It is best to edit only those parameters that you are familiar with. Incorrect changes may affect the integrity of the data. We recommend that you do not overwrite the original data file.

Url.Title: Error Loading Initialization File
Url.Abstract: Error Loading Initialization File Error loading initialization file. An error occurred while attempting to load an initialization file during the running of a macro. The initialization file could be corrupted and is not usable or the problem could be with the macro itself.

Url.Title: Error Processing Mass Spectrometer File
Url.Abstract: Error Processing Mass Spectrometer File An error was encountered while processing a Mass Spectrometer data file. The converted data file is not saved. Examine the specified data cycle in the Mass Spectrometer file for formatting errors.

Url.Title: Error While Running Macro
Url.Abstract: Error While Running Macro

Url.Title: Error Writing Autoqueue File
Url.Abstract: Error Writing Autoqueue File

Url.Title: Exit Program
Url.Abstract: Exit Program This is a confirmation message to ensure that you want to exit the program. Select Cancel to abort this operation and return to the program.

Url.Title: Export Plot in Progress
Url.Abstract: Export Plot in Progress The function you have chosen cannot be performed until the current export operation is finished. Please wait.

Url.Title: File Access Error
Url.Abstract: File Access Error File Creation Error File Open Error File Read Error File Write Error A file system error occurred while accessing the specified file.

Url.Title: File Exists Messages
Url.Abstract: File Exists Messages Problem: A file, with the name and folder specified, already exists on your computer. If you continue with the operation, the existing file will be overwritten.

Url.Title: File Must Contain Text
Url.Abstract: File Must Contain Text Problem: The text file specified does not have a .txt extension, indicating a plain text (text only) file. No conversion to plain text is provided for non-text file types (e.g., .rtf, .doc, etc.). If the specified file is a plain text file, but does not have a .txt extension, then this warning message can be ignored.

Url.Title: Find String Not Found
Url.Abstract: Find String Not Found This is an informational message to let you know that the document has been searched and the characters that you entered have not been found in the current document.

Url.Title: First Partial Area Slice is Too Large
Url.Abstract: First Partial Area Slice is Too Large Problem: You have entered an incorrect value under the analysis option "First partial area height cut off" or for the peak limits.

Url.Title: Geometry Mismatch
Url.Abstract: Geometry Mismatch Problem: This is a warning message that the calculations used in the instrument to compute sample geometry are different from the calculation in the data analysis program. If there is no sample geometry in the data file, or there is an unsupported geometry in the data file, this message will occur.

Url.Title: Graphic Weight Not Available
Url.Abstract: Graphic Weight Not Available

Url.Title: Inactive While Running Macro
Url.Abstract: Inactive While Running Macro Problem: This message is displayed if you switch to another application or function while Universal Analysis is running a macro and focus cannot be automatically restored.

Url.Title: Incompatible Analysis Records
Url.Abstract: Incompatible Analysis Records Problem: The saved analysis in this data file is from a different program.

Url.Title: Incompatible Record Size
Url.Abstract: Incompatible Record Size Problem: One of the saved analysis records stored in this data file is larger than expected.

Url.Title: Installation Error
Url.Abstract: Installation Error Problem: The Universal Analysis program was not installed from the distribution CD-ROM or the installation was corrupted.

Url.Title: Insufficient Columns
Url.Abstract: Insufficient Columns This message is displayed when you attempt to paste an insufficient number of columns from the clipboard into a larger number of highlighted columns in the spreadsheet. For example, if you copy one column of data to the clipboard and attempt to paste it into two highlighted columns on the spreadsheet, you will get this message.

Url.Title: Insufficient Memory for Macro Operation
Url.Abstract: Insufficient Memory for Macro Operation 1. Close one or more nonessential applications. 2. Close one or more open files in the analysis program.

Url.Title: Insufficient Parameters
Url.Abstract: Insufficient Parameters

Url.Title: Insufficient Resources
Url.Abstract: Insufficient Resources

Url.Title: Insufficient Room for Macro Steps
Url.Abstract: Insufficient Room for Macro Steps Insufficient room. Cannot paste macro steps. Problem: You have copied several macro steps and attempted to paste them into an existing macro; however, there is not enough room for all of the macro steps. (A maximum of 800 macro steps can be included in one macro.)

Url.Title: Insufficient Rows
Url.Abstract: Insufficient Rows This message is displayed when you attempt to paste an insufficient number of rows from the clipboard into a larger number of highlighted rows in the spreadsheet. For example, if you copy one row of data to the clipboard and attempt to paste it into four highlighted rows on the spreadsheet, you will get this message.

Url.Title: Integration Weight Too Small
Url.Abstract: Integration Weight Too Small

Url.Title: Intervening Peak
Url.Abstract: Intervening Peak Problem: You attempted to perform a peak analysis over a region of the curve that contains an already-defined, peak or smaller subpeak.

Url.Title: Invalid Autoqueue Record
Url.Abstract: Invalid Autoqueue Record Problem: You have attempted to paste information from the clipboard into the autoqueue, but the information does not contain the proper and/or complete analysis record information. A record contains a filename, macro filename, macro, and comment.

Url.Title: Invalid Dialog Button
Url.Abstract: Invalid Dialog Button

Url.Title: Invalid Directory Path
Url.Abstract: Invalid Directory Path Problem: The directory path specified cannot be located on your system. Solution:

Url.Title: Invalid File Path
Url.Abstract: Invalid File Path Problem: The file path specified cannot be located on your system. Solution: Check that you specified the file path correctly or located a file using the Browse button.

Url.Title: Invalid Grid Index
Url.Abstract: Invalid Grid Index

Url.Title: Invalid Inset Region
Url.Abstract: Invalid Inset Region This message is displayed if you attempt to set the region limits for the x-minimum value equal to the x-maximum value or the y-minimum value equal to the y-maximum value on the Inset View window. The inset region must have a non-zero width and height.

Url.Title: Invalid Item Index
Url.Abstract: Invalid Item Index

Url.Title: Invalid Number
Url.Abstract: Invalid Number The value entered is not a valid number or contains an illegal character for this field. Please delete the entry and try again.

Url.Title: Invalid Number
Url.Abstract: Invalid Number This message is displayed when you attempt to paste something from the clipboard to the spreadsheet that is not recognized as a valid number by the program. The item on the clipboard may be an alphabetic character or an image, etc. and as such cannot be a valid number.

Url.Title: Invalid Parameter Block
Url.Abstract: Invalid Parameter Block

Url.Title: Invalid Record ID
Url.Abstract: Invalid Record ID Problem: An invalid record ID was found in a string. The record ID cannot be decoded.

Url.Title: Invalid Sigmoidal Baseline
Url.Abstract: Invalid Sigmoidal Baseline Problem: The sigmoidal baseline for one or more results may be invalid. The data in memory that was used to calculate the baseline(s) has changed.

Url.Title: Invalid Variable Character
Url.Abstract: Invalid Variable Character Problem: You have attempted to enter an invalid character into a variable name in a macro.

Url.Title: Jump Target Incorrect
Url.Abstract: Jump Target Incorrect Problem: The number of text lines in a multi-line macro dialog containing a "Jump" step has changed because "Extended Text" steps, following a "Dialog" step, have been inserted or deleted. This message alerts you that the target step for your "Jump" step may now be incorrect.

Url.Title: Less Than Two Points File
Url.Abstract: Less Than Two Points File There are less than two data points in the data file. A minimum of two data points is required. If this data file is currently open for data collection, then wait for buffered data to be written to the data file before reading the file.

Url.Title: Less Than Two Points Limit
Url.Abstract: Less Than Two Points Limit There are less than two data points between the Start and Stop limits specified. A minimum of two data points is required. If this data file is currently open for data collection, then wait for buffered data over the specified range to be written to the data file before reading the file.

Url.Title: Limits Out of Order
Url.Abstract: Limits Out of Order

Url.Title: Line Too Long
Url.Abstract: Line Too Long Problem: The line of text that you entered is too long. Solution: Delete some text.

Url.Title: Line Too Long
Url.Abstract: Line Too Long Problem: Each line of text contained in the macro dialog box can be only 60 characters long. You have attempted to enter too many characters in a line.

Url.Title: Load Data Error
Url.Abstract: Load Data Error This is a general informational error message, usually preceeded by another program or Windows error message. This error occurs while the data file is being read.

Url.Title: Logout from Database?
Url.Abstract: Logout from Database? Problem: This message is displayed when you select File/Logout from the main menu during a 21 CFR 11 Universal Analysis session.

Url.Title: Macro Cannot Execute Itself
Url.Abstract: Macro Cannot Execute Itself

Url.Title: Macro Step Target is Disabled
Url.Abstract: Macro Step Target is Disabled

Url.Title: Mass Number Problem
Url.Abstract: Mass Number Problem This message is displayed when you attempt to open a Mass Spectrometer file in Universal Analysis and the program cannot locate or read the mass numbers. The mass number data that the program is attempting to read starts on the next line after the line with the header "Enabled m/e Statistic Info."

Url.Title: Math Error
Url.Abstract: Math Error Problem: An invalid operation (e.g., dividing a number by zero) occurred in the programs calcu∀la∀tions.

Url.Title: Maximum Analysis Steps
Url.Abstract: Maximum Analysis Steps Problem: The analysis log can only record up to 800 analysis steps for a single open data file. Any further analysis steps are not recorded.

Url.Title: Maximum Axis Range Exceeded
Url.Abstract: Maximum Axis Range Exceeded Problem: The plot axis range limits have been exceeded. Solution: Increase the axis scale start value or decrease the axis scale stop value.

Url.Title: Maximum Curves Defined
Url.Abstract: Maximum Curves Defined Problem: You have already defined the maximum number of curves (10) that can be displayed on the current axis in Curve Overlay.

Url.Title: Maximum Files Open
Url.Abstract: Maximum Files Open

Url.Title: Maximum Macros Defined
Url.Abstract: Maximum Macros Defined

Url.Title: Maximum Number of Macro Steps
Url.Abstract: Maximum Number of Macro Steps

Url.Title: Maximum Number of Variables Defined
Url.Abstract: Maximum Number of Variables Defined Problem: The running macro cannot have any more than 200 defined variables. This total includes both the current macro and any macros called from within that macro containing additional defined variables.

Url.Title: Mismatched Apostrophes
Url.Abstract: Mismatched Apostrophes Mismatched apostrophes in quoted text. Problem: A quotes text string in a macro "Assign " step has mismatched quotes.

Url.Title: Must Save to Initialization File
Url.Abstract: Must Save to Initialization File This change will not take effect until it is saved to the current initialization file.

Url.Title: Maximum Table Length Exceeded
Url.Abstract: Maximum Table Length Exceeded Problem: The maximum length of a data table (32767 lines) has been reached while generating a data table report.

Url.Title: More Than Ten Curves
Url.Abstract: More Than Ten Curves

Url.Title: Negative Time Not Allowed
Url.Abstract: Negative Time Not Allowed You have altered the data and created negative time data. Since time cannot be negative, the new file will be saved without the negative values for time. This message prompts you to decide if you want to write the new file without these negative data values for time.

Url.Title: No Annotation Text
Url.Abstract: No Annotation Text Problem: The text fields for a plot annotation are completely blank. Solution: Use at least one nonblank character in the annotation text.

Url.Title: No Comment Text
Url.Abstract: No Comment Text Problem: No comment text was entered in one of the following windows: Macro Comment, Audit Trail Comment, or Analysis Log Comment.

Url.Title: No Compatible Signals
Url.Abstract: No Compatible Signals Problem: To create a curve overlay graph the signals from the source files must have compatible signals. The source file you selected does not have signals that are compatible with the other files being used.

Url.Title: No Data Between Limits
Url.Abstract: No Data Between Limits Problem: There are no data points found between the data limits you have selected.

Url.Title: No Data in File
Url.Abstract: No Data in File This data file contains only the version information in the parameter block. If the data file is currently open for data collection, then wait until the first buffer of data points is stored before reading the file. If the file is not currently being collected, then it has been truncated or prematurely terminated during data collection. Wait until all data has been collected before transferring your data.

Url.Title: No Initialization File
Url.Abstract: No Initialization File Universal Analysis cannot obtain sufficient dynamic memory from the operating system to load and save initialization (ini) files. The save or load operation has been aborted. Close some open applications and repeat the operation.

Url.Title: No Labels Visible
Url.Abstract: No Labels Visible Problem: You attempted to adjust a label position when no labels are visible on the plot.
