Url.Abstract: Checkbox Label with End Check this box to label the graph with the end of the step/glass transition.

Url.Title: Checkbox Label with Limits
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Label with Limits Check this box to label the graph with the x-axis value at the limit points.

Url.Title: Checkbox Label with Onset
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Label with Onset Check this box to label the graph with the onset of the step/glass transition.

Url.Title: Checkbox Label with Signed Change
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Label with Signed Change Check this box to label the graph with the appropriately signed change value. If the change is negative, a minus sign will be shown with the numerical value. If the change is positive, no sign will be shown with the numerical value, positive is implied.

Url.Title: Checkbox Label with Signed Delta Cp
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Label with Signed Delta Cp Check this box to label the graph with the appropriately signed change in heat capacity (Cp) value. If the heat capacity is negative, a minus sign will be shown with the numerical value. If the heat capacity is positive, no sign will be shown with the numerical value, positive is implied.

Url.Title: Checkbox Suppress Arrowheads on Result Lines
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Suppress Arrowheads on Result Lines When Arrowheads are displayed any result lines are drawn with arrowheads pointing to the point(s) on the curve.

Url.Title: Checkbox Multicolor Table
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Multicolor Table Check Multicolor table to have the multicolor option (defined on the Main Options - Color Page) assigned to each line of a vertical multiplexed signal table. This option is only available with multiplex data files (e.g., DMA and DEA frequency, DMA amplitude, and µTA location).

Url.Title: Temperature
Url.Abstract: Temperature Check this box to label the selected data point on the graph with the temperature.

Url.Title: Checkbox Multicolor Text
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Multicolor Text Check Multicolor text to have the multicolor option (defined on the Main Options - Color Page) assigned to each line of text created in the Text field.

Url.Title: Checkbox TGA Limits Label
Url.Abstract: Checkbox TGA Limits Label Check this box to display the x-axis value at the limit points during TGA step change, weight change, and/or residue analyses.

Url.Title: Checkbox TGA Percent Label
Url.Abstract: Checkbox TGA Percent Label Check this box to label a TGA step change, weight change, or residue analysis with the percentage value.

Url.Title: Checkbox TGA Signed Change
Url.Abstract: Checkbox TGA Signed Change Check this box to label a TGA result with the appropriately signed change value. If the weight change is negative, a minus sign will be shown with the numerical value. If the weight change is positive, no sign will be shown with the numerical value, positive is implied.

Url.Title: Checkbox TGA Transition Label
Url.Abstract: Checkbox TGA Transition Label Check this box to label a TGA step change, weight change, or residue analysis with the transition label.

Url.Title: Checkbox TGA Weight Label
Url.Abstract: Checkbox TGA Weight Label Check this box to label a TGA step change, weight change, or residue analysis with the weight.

Url.Title: Checkbox Time and Temperature
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Time and Temperature Check this box to output both time and temperature to a data table report or data table spreadsheet. This information will be added to any other data already included. Leave the box blank to output only the currently displayed x- and y-axis signals.

Url.Title: Time
Url.Abstract: Time Check this box to label the selected data point on the graph with the time.

Url.Title: Checkbox TMA Percent Calculated
Url.Abstract: Checkbox TMA Percent Calculated Check this box to calculate the percent value by dividing the expansion over the temperature range by the corrected size of the sample. The corrected length is calculated at the first temperature entered.

Url.Title: Checkbox Transparent
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Transparent Check this box to make the background of the label text transparent.

Url.Title: Checkbox Use Known Pure Heat of Fusion
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Use Known Pure Heat of Fusion Check the box for Use known pure heat of fusion to perform the purity calculations on your data using the known heat of fusion for the sample material. If you check this box, you will need to enter the value for the heat of fusion in kJ/mol.

Url.Title: Checkbox Use Known Molecular Weight
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Use Known Molecular Weight Check the box for Use known molecular weight to perform the calculations on your data using the known molecular weight of the sample material. If you check this box, you will need to enter the value in g/mol.

Url.Title: Checkbox Use XP Themes
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Use XP Themes Check this box on the Main Options  Initialization Page, to have Universal Analysis display windows and dialogs using the currently selected XP Theme on a Windows XP system. Uncheck this box to display windows and dialogs in Window classic style.

Url.Title: Show View Border Checkbox
Url.Abstract: Show View Border Checkbox Check this box to put a border around the inset view and make it opaque. If Border is checked, the inset view will cover anything underneath it. Click here for an example of an inset view with a border.

Url.Title: Show X Axis Scale Checkbox
Url.Abstract: Show X Axis Scale Checkbox Check this box to display the x axis in the inset view. Click here for an example of an inset view showing the x-axis scale.

Url.Title: Signal
Url.Abstract: Signal Check this box to label the selected data point on the graph with the signal. This signal is selected on the Signal Selection window. You do not have to select the Signal radio button on the Signal Selection window. In this manner, any point can be labeled with any of the X signals saved when the data was collected.

Url.Title: Checkbox Y4 Axis
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Y4 Axis In either case, the fit data curve is drawn on the Y4 axis.

Url.Title: Show Y Axis Scale Checkbox
Url.Abstract: Show Y Axis Scale Checkbox Check this box to display the y axis in the inset view. Click here for an example of an inset view showing the y-axis scale.

Url.Title: Checkbox Y Signals
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Y Signals Check the desired Y signal boxes to automatically use the selected Y signal(s) for a curve overlay graph, when available in the selected data files.

Url.Title: Y Axis Value
Url.Abstract: Y Axis Value Check this box to label the selected data point on the graph with the Y-axis value.

Url.Title: Choosing the Phase Correction Range
Url.Abstract: Choosing the Phase Correction Range Modulated DSC (MDSC®) analysis has generally been used to measure the heat capacity (Cp) of a material. However, the MDSC technique can also be used to calculate phase-lag and its contribution to the measured heat capacity signal. The Thermal Advantage Universal Analysis program contains algorithms that allow you to calculate the Reversing Heat Capacity and Nonreversing Heat Capacity signals, as well as the phase correctedReversing Heat Flow and Nonreversing Heat Flow signals. Total heat flow is not affected by deviations in the heat flow phase.

Url.Title: Scale Bar Colors
Url.Abstract: Scale Bar Colors Click on the desired color for the scale bar and its label. The FG (foreground) mark will be displayed in the selected color block.

Url.Title: Cell Constant
Url.Abstract: Cell Constant

Url.Title: Comments
Url.Abstract: Comments Enter additional text to help describe the experiment, for example, sample treatment or experimental conditions could be included. Up to 64 characters may be entered. This information will appear in the plot header of the printed graph.

Url.Title: Exotherm Up/Down
Url.Abstract: Exotherm Up/Down Select Exotherm Up to plot your heat flow or temperature difference data in the traditional TA Instruments format, with the exothermic portion of the curve in the upward direction.

Url.Title: Method
Url.Abstract: Method Use this field to enter a short description of the method used to gather this data file. A method file contains an ordered list of segments that will instruct the instrument's functions throughout the course of the experiment. This information will appear in the plot header of the printed graph.

Url.Title: Operator
Url.Abstract: Operator Enter the name used to identify the person conducting the thermal analysis experiment. Up to 25 characters may be entered. This information will appear in the plot header of the printed graph.

Url.Title: Sample Name
Url.Abstract: Sample Name Enter the identification of the sample material used in this experiment. Up to 32 characters may be entered. This information will appear in the plot header of the printed graph.

Url.Title: Sample Size
Url.Abstract: Sample Size Enter the sample weight in the appropriate units. This information will appear in the plot header of the printed graph.

Url.Title: Entry Field Alpha at a Point Smoothing Width
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Alpha at a Point Smoothing Width Alpha is calculated as the slope of a least squares linear fit to the dimension and temperature data region around the given temperature. The size of this linear fit region is the "alpha at a point smoothing width" analysis parameter. The region is truncated if it extends outside the analysis limits or data collection region. If the given temperature is outside the analysis limits or is in a region where data was not collected, then the calculation of alpha is suppressed.

Url.Title: Entry Field Analysis Data Cycle
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Analysis Data Cycle Enter the cycle number that will be used for analysis.

Url.Title: Entry Field Analysis Region Width
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Analysis Region Width Enter the width of the desired analysis region. For example, if you enter 5 for an X-axis showing temperature, data from every 5 degrees is grouped together and averaged by the method of least squares. The resultant plot is a measure of the signal sensitivity during any portion of the experiment.

Url.Title: Entry Area Correction Factor High Limit
Url.Abstract: Entry Area Correction Factor High Limit Enter the upper limits of the area correction factor as the Constraints on area correction factor.

Url.Title: Entry Area Correction Factor Low Limit
Url.Abstract: Entry Area Correction Factor Low Limit Enter the lower limits of the area correction factor as the Constraints on area correction factor.

Url.Title: Entry Audit Trail Comment
Url.Abstract: Entry Audit Trail Comment Enter the desired comment to add to the audit trail log for the current data file or click the Clipboard button to paste the information copied to the clipboard in the comment entry field. The maximum length of each line is 60 characters and up to 30 lines of text can be entered for a single comment. NOTE: You can clear the description box by clicking the Clear button.

Url.Title: Entry Auto Refresh Time
Url.Abstract: Entry Auto Refresh Time Enter the time that will elapse between refreshing of the plotted data from an active data file (real time plot). The default time is five seconds.

Url.Title: Entry Field Axis Label Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Axis Label Name Use this entry field to edit the name of the axis displayed here, if desired. Maximum characters = 40.

Url.Title: Entry Correct Heat Flow Minimum Weight
Url.Abstract: Entry Correct Heat Flow Minimum Weight Enter the desired weight value (in percent) that will be used as the minimum value for corrected SDT heat flow data analysis. The default value is 5 percent.

Url.Title: Entry Data Buffer Size
Url.Abstract: Entry Data Buffer Size Enter the desired buffer size to use for your data files. A data compaction option will be applied in the event a data file exceeds this size.

Url.Title: Entry Data Files
Url.Abstract: Entry Data Files Use this field to enter the default directory location of your data files. This entry will be used when the program is first started. Each time a data file is opened after this initial time, the last path that you selected will be used.

Url.Title: Entry Data Table Increment
Url.Abstract: Entry Data Table Increment Enter the increment to set the spacing between the reported values. For example, an increment of 0.1 causes the program to report a data point from every 0.1 unit of time or temperature.

Url.Title: Entry Data Table Start
Url.Abstract: Entry Data Table Start Enter the point at which the program will start using the data to create the data table report.

Url.Title: Entry Data Table Stop
Url.Abstract: Entry Data Table Stop Enter the point at which the program will stop using the data to create the data table report.

Url.Title: Entry Delay Time
Url.Abstract: Entry Delay Time Enter the time, in the displayed units, at which you want the program to begin searching for the specified temperature range. For experiments in which the designated temperature range is cycled, the delay time option enables you to skip over earlier cycles and select data from later cycles in the experiment. For example, a delay time of 5.00 minutes tells the program to skip all data generated before the fifth minute of the experiment.

Url.Title: Entry Desmearing Derivative
Url.Abstract: Entry Desmearing Derivative Enter the derivative window (in seconds) that you want applied to the curve for desmearing purposes.

Url.Title: Entry Desmearing Time Constant
Url.Abstract: Entry Desmearing Time Constant Enter the time constant (in seconds). For example, in DSC this is the time constant of the calorimeter.

Url.Title: Entry Export Files
Url.Abstract: Entry Export Files Use this field to enter the default directory location to be used when exporting files.

Url.Title: Entry Field Height
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Height Enter the desired height of the exported plot, in percent or pixels.

Url.Title: Entry Field Pen Width
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Pen Width Enter the desired width of the pen stroke to be used when plotting the exported plot.

Url.Title: Entry field Plot Heading
Url.Abstract: Entry field Plot Heading Enter the plot heading that you want to have printed on your curve overlay graph each time one is created using the Auto Configure option. The plot heading will not be displayed, it will only be PRINTED or EXPORTED. See also: Print Preview window.

Url.Title: Entry Field Plot Heading Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Plot Heading Text Enter up to four lines of 76 characters that will be used for plot header information.

Url.Title: Entry Field Plot Legend Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Plot Legend Text Type the desired text that will be added to the bottom of the legend. 5,000 characters can be entered. If Multicolor text is checked, the "Multicolors" defined on the Main Options - Color Page will be assigned to each line of text. After 12 lines have been assigned colors, the color selection will be repeated for the remaining lines.

Url.Title: Entry Field Overlay Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Overlay Name Enter the desired name (maximum of 80 characters) for the overlay window that will be created. This name will appear in the window title and Windows menu only. It is used to identify one curve overlay plot from another.

Url.Title: Entry Field Width
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Width Enter the desired width of the exported plot, in percent or pixels.

Url.Title: Entry Field X Offset
Url.Abstract: Entry Field X Offset Use this entry field to enter the offset value, which represents the X-axis units. The X offset value allows curves to be offset from each other in the x direction.

Url.Title: Entry Field File Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Field File Name Enter a drive, directory, and filename. See also:

Url.Title: Entry Final Weight
Url.Abstract: Entry Final Weight Enter the weight at which you would like to end the analyses.

Url.Title: Entry First Partial Area Height Cutoff
Url.Abstract: Entry First Partial Area Height Cutoff Enter the First partial area height cutoff (fraction of peak maxi∀mum) as a decimal [the default is 0.1 (10 percent)]. The first partial area begins at the left edge of the peak range, and extends to the point where the signal is a specified fraction of the peak height below the baseline.

Url.Title: X-Axis Name Entry Field
Url.Abstract: X-Axis Name Entry Field Edit or enter the X-axis name to be used as the axis label.

Url.Title: Y-Axis Name Entry Field
Url.Abstract: Y-Axis Name Entry Field Edit or enter the Y-axis name to be used as the axis label.

Url.Title: Entry Initialization Files
Url.Abstract: Entry Initialization Files Use this field to enter the default directory location to be used for your initialization (.ini) files.

Url.Title: Entry Initial Wm, Cg, and K Constants
Url.Abstract: Entry Initial Wm, Cg, and K Constants Enter an initial value for each of the GAB constants. The regression analysis will start with these values and then try to improve the fit of the GAB equation to the raw data.

Url.Title: X View Handle Position
Url.Abstract: X View Handle Position Use this field to enter the default x coordinate on the graph for the position of the handle for the inset view. The coordinates are unitless, and range from 0.0 to 1.0 on the axis.

Url.Title: View Size X Direction
Url.Abstract: View Size X Direction Enter the percentage of the main plots x axis that will be used for the inset view.

Url.Title: Y View Handle Position
Url.Abstract: Y View Handle Position Use this field to enter the default y coordinate on the graph for the position of the handle for the inset view. The coordinates are unitless, and range from 0.0 to 1.0 on the axis.

Url.Title: View Size Y Direction
Url.Abstract: View Size Y Direction Enter the percentage of the main plots y axis that will be used for the inset view.

Url.Title: Entry Use Known Pure Heat of Fusion
Url.Abstract: Entry Use Known Pure Heat of Fusion

Url.Title: Entry Known Molecular Weight
Url.Abstract: Entry Known Molecular Weight Enter the known molecular weight for the sample material in g/mol.

Url.Title: Entry Label Interval
Url.Abstract: Entry Label Interval The label interval determines how often the axis is numbered. (For log axis scaling, the label interval must be a multiple of 9.0.)

Url.Title: Entry Label Offset
Url.Abstract: Entry Label Offset Enter the offset to the place on each of the axes where you want the first label to appear. The first label offset enables you to start labeling the graph at any point you choose. For example, if the axis starts at 0.03, but you want the first label to appear at 0.05, enter 0.02 (the difference between the start limit and the point on the axis where you want the first label to appear). (For log axis scaling, the offset must be 0.00.)

Url.Title: Entry Fields Linear Transform Equation
Url.Abstract: Entry Fields Linear Transform Equation Enter the values desired. These values apply the resulting equation to adjust the slope and/or intercept of the selected axis. This can be used, for example, to change to different units.

Url.Title: Entry Macro Files
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Files Use this field to enter the default directory location to be used when saving macro files.

Url.Title: Entry Manual Value
Url.Abstract: Entry Manual Value Enter the desired weight value to be used for integration analyses.

Url.Title: Entry Maximum Partial Area
Url.Abstract: Entry Maximum Partial Area Enter the Maximum partial area (fraction of peak area) as a decimal [the default is 0.5 (50 percent of the total area)]. The last partial area ends when it exceeds or equals this fraction of the total peak area.

Url.Title: Entry Modify Data Value
Url.Abstract: Entry Modify Data Value Enter the desired data value in this field. The data value will be modified in both the spreadsheet and graph view so that you can perform analysis functions, etc. using the modified data.

Url.Title: Entry Molecular Weight
Url.Abstract: Entry Molecular Weight Enter the molecular weight for the sample material in g/mol. This is used to determine the purity calculations.

Url.Title: Entry New Size
Url.Abstract: Entry New Size Enter the new sample size. The sample size and size-related signals (e.g., Weight, Weight Change, Dimension Change, Length) will be modified to reflect the new sample size.

Url.Title: Entry Number of Partial Areas
Url.Abstract: Entry Number of Partial Areas Enter the desired Number of partial areas (the default value is 25). The number of partial areas is computed by the program and used in the purity calculations. The reciprocals of these partial areas are spaced ap∀proximately equal.

Url.Title: Entry Inflection Offset (Onset Point)
Url.Abstract: Entry Inflection Offset (Onset Point) Enter the desired offset from the inflection point on the curve relative to the onset. These values are relative to the x-axis scale. For example, if you enter 20 x-axis units as the inflection offset, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the right of the inflection. If you enter 20 x-axis units, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the left of the inflection.

Url.Title: Entry Field File Name (Curve Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Entry Field File Name (Curve Overlay) Use this field to edit the filename of the selected curve, if desired. (NOTE: The filenames are automatically displayed when you add curves using the Add Curves button.)

Url.Title: Entry Field Oxidation Gas Start
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Oxidation Gas Start Use this field to enter the oxidation gas start, which is the time when you started the use of oxygen in your experiment.

Url.Title: Entry Inflection Offset (Oxidation)
Url.Abstract: Entry Inflection Offset (Oxidation) Enter the desired maximum offset from the inflection point on the curve relative to the oxidation point. These values are relative to the x-axis scale. For example, if you enter 20 x-axis units as the inflection offset, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the right of the inflection. If you enter 20 x-axis units, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the left of the inflection.

Url.Title: Entry Peak Max Offset
Url.Abstract: Entry Peak Max Offset Enter an offset value relative to the current peak maximum, which will be used to determine the analysis limit. These values are also relative to the x-axis scale. For example, if you enter 20 x-axis units as the peak max offset, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the right of the peak maximum. If you enter 20 x-axis units, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the left of the peak maximum.

Url.Title: Entry Penalty Factor
Url.Abstract: Entry Penalty Factor (Larger value forces smaller area correction.) Enter the desired Penalty factor (larger value forces smaller area correc∀tion). The penalty factor is used to bias the results towards a smaller area correction. A penalty factor of one means that the fit is determined entirely by the squared deviation between the data and the modified vant Hoff equation. A penalty factor greater than one results in a deviation multiplied by a function that tends to make smaller area correc∀tions fit better. The default value is 1.0.

Url.Title: Entry Pens
Url.Abstract: Entry Pens Enter the number of pens that your HPGL plotter uses.

Url.Title: Entry Field Percentage
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Percentage Enter the percent value of the total axis range that you want to offset the Y-axis curves. This value defines the amount of Y-axis offset for each curve. No offset is applied for the first curve on the axis.

Url.Title: Entry Plot Legend Heading
Url.Abstract: Entry Plot Legend Heading Use this field to enter your own characters on the legend. Place the cursor in this field and then enter the desired heading for the legend.

Url.Title: X Manual Position
Url.Abstract: X Manual Position Use this field to enter the default x coordinate on the graph for the position of the legend. The coordinates are unitless, and range from 0.0 to 1.0 on the axis.

Url.Title: Y Manual Position
Url.Abstract: Y Manual Position Use this field to enter the default y coordinate on the graph for the position of the legend. The coordinates are unitless, and range from 0.0 to 1.0 on the axis.

Url.Title: Entry Point
Url.Abstract: Entry Point Enter the X and Y point values for the selected limit point.

Url.Title: Entry Field Poisson Ratio
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Poisson Ratio Enter value desired for the Poisson's ratio. This is a DMA parameter that defines the ratio of transverse contraction per unit dimension to the elongation per unit length, when the sample is subjected to a tensile stress.

Url.Title: Region Limits X Maximum
Url.Abstract: Region Limits X Maximum Enter the maximum X-axis data limits to be used for the inset view.

Url.Title: Region Limits X Minimum
Url.Abstract: Region Limits X Minimum Enter the minimum X-axis data limits to be used for the inset view.

Url.Title: Region Limits Y Maximum
Url.Abstract: Region Limits Y Maximum Enter the maximum X-axis data limits to be used for the inset view.

Url.Title: Region Limits Y Minimum
Url.Abstract: Region Limits Y Minimum Enter the minimum Y-axis data limits to be used for the inset view.

Url.Title: Entry Report Files
Url.Abstract: Entry Report Files Use this field to enter the default directory location to be used when saving report files.

Url.Title: Entry Relative Humidity High
Url.Abstract: Entry Relative Humidity High Enter the upper limit for relative humidity. Only data points with relative humidity values less than this limit will be included in the analysis.

Url.Title: Entry Relative Humidity Low
Url.Abstract: Entry Relative Humidity Low Enter the lower limit for relative humidity. Only data points with relative humidity values greater than this limit will be included in the analysis.

Url.Title: Entry R Squared Limit
Url.Abstract: Entry R Squared Limit Enter the R² limit for terminating the GAB regression analysis. The fitting process will terminate when the R² limit is reached or after 100 attempts to fit the data.

Url.Title: Entry Sample Size
Url.Abstract: Entry Sample Size Enter a non-zero sample size.

Url.Title: Scale Bar Width
Url.Abstract: Scale Bar Width Enter the desired width of the scale bar. The units that are displayed here depend on whether the direction selected is Horizontal (x-axis units displayed) or Vertical (current y-axis units displayed). The scale bar created will represent the entered width on the graph.

Url.Title: Entry Field Show Legend Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Show Legend Text Use this field to edit the legend text that will be applied, if the Text box has been checked. This is a customizable label used to distinguish curves in the graph legend. The text defaults to the sample identification found in the data file. The maximum number of characters is 32.

Url.Title: Entry Derivative Fraction (Signal Change)
Url.Abstract: Entry Derivative Fraction (Signal Change) Enter the Derivation fraction to determine the signal change using the point determined by the derivative fraction entered.

Url.Title: Entry Field Signal Threshold
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Signal Threshold

Url.Title: Entry Field Smoothing Region Width
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Smoothing Region Width Enter the width of the desired smoothing region. For example, if you enter 5 for an X-axis showing temperature, data from every 5 degrees is grouped together and averaged by the method of least squares. The resulting averages are then plotted on the screen.

Url.Title: Entry Start
Url.Abstract: Entry Start The start limit determines the signal value at which the axis begins. (For log axis scaling, the limit must be at a full decade interval.)

Url.Title: Entry Field Start Phase Baseline Limits
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Start Phase Baseline Limits Enter the desired start limit for the data to be used for MDSC phase correction.

Url.Title: Entry Start Weight
Url.Abstract: Entry Start Weight Enter the weight at which you would like to begin the analyses.

Url.Title: Entry Inflection Offset (Step/Glass Transition)
Url.Abstract: Entry Inflection Offset (Step/Glass Transition) Enter the desired offset from the transitions inflection point on the curve. These values are relative to the x-axis scale. For example, if you enter 20 x-axis units as the inflection offset, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the right of the inflection. If you enter 20 x-axis units, it will be interpreted as 20 units to the left of the inflection.

Url.Title: Entry Stop
Url.Abstract: Entry Stop The stop limit determines the signal value at which the axis ends. (For log axis scaling, the limit must be at a full decade interval.)

Url.Title: Entry Field Stop Phase Baseline Limits
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Stop Phase Baseline Limits Enter the desired stop limit for the data to be used for MDSC phase correction.

Url.Title: Entry Ticks/Label on X Axis
Url.Abstract: Entry Ticks/Label on X Axis Enter the desired number of tick marks per axis label for the x axis. The default number is 4 ticks/label.

Url.Title: Entry Ticks/Label on Y Axis
Url.Abstract: Entry Ticks/Label on Y Axis Enter the desired number of tick marks per axis label for the y axis. The default number is 4 ticks/label.

Url.Title: Entry Tick Interval
Url.Abstract: Entry Tick Interval The tick interval determines how often the axis is marked to show increments in the signal.

Url.Title: Entry Field Transition Label Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Transition Label Text Use this field to enter a maximum of 15 characters to identify the transition, if desired.

Url.Title: Entry Use Known Pure Melting Temperature
Url.Abstract: Entry Use Known Pure Melting Temperature Enter the known melting temperature for the pure sample material in °C.

Url.Title: Entry Derivative Fraction
Url.Abstract: Entry Derivative Fraction Enter the Derivation fraction to determine the weight change or signal change using the point determined by the derivative fraction entered.

Url.Title: Entry Field X Manual Position
Url.Abstract: Entry Field X Manual Position Select the x coordinates on the graph for the manual positioning of the legend. The coordinates are unitless and range from 0.0 to 1.0 on the X axis. (NOTE: When the curve overlay window is displayed, you can drag and drop the legend anywhere on the graph.)

Url.Title: Entry X Max
Url.Abstract: Entry X Max Enter the X max value based on your plotter type listed in the table below: -0.0250 1.0115 6 HP-7475

Url.Title: Entry X Min
Url.Abstract: Entry X Min Enter the X min value based on your plotter type listed in the table below: -0.0250 1.0115 6 HP-7475

Url.Title: Entry Field Y Manual Position
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Y Manual Position Select the y coordinates on the graph for the manual positioning of the legend. The coordinates are unitless and range from 0.0 to 1.0 on the Y axis. (NOTE: When the curve overlay window is displayed, you can drag and drop the legend anywhere on the graph.)

Url.Title: Entry Field Y Offset
Url.Abstract: Entry Field Y Offset Enter the desired offset value, which represents the Y-axis units, to allow the curves to be offset in the y direction.

Url.Title: Examples Auto Color Checkbox (Curve Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Examples Auto Color Checkbox (Curve Overlay) When using the Auto Color checkbox on the Auto Configure window, the following applies:

Url.Title: Examples Auto Line Checkbox (Curve Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Examples Auto Line Checkbox (Curve Overlay) When using the Auto Line checkbox on the Auto Configure window, the following applies:

Url.Title: Examples Auto Symbol Checkbox (Curve Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Examples Auto Symbol Checkbox (Curve Overlay) When using the Auto Symbol checkbox on the Auto Configure window, the following applies:

Url.Abstract: Example Inset View

Url.Title: Example of Inset View Showing One Curve
Url.Abstract: Example of Inset View Showing One Curve

Url.Title: Example of Inset View Showing Y Axis
Url.Abstract: Example of Inset View Showing Y Axis

Url.Title: Example of Partial Results Hidden
Url.Abstract: Example of Partial Results Hidden

Url.Title: Example of Partial Results Shown
Url.Abstract: Example of Partial Results Shown

Url.Title: Example of Scale Bar
Url.Abstract: Example of Scale Bar

Url.Title: Example TGA Inset View
Url.Abstract: Example TGA Inset View

Url.Title: Examples Y Signals (Curve Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Examples Y Signals (Curve Overlay) If several data files are chosen for Curve Overlay that have signals plotted on axes Y1, Y2, and Y3, checking just the Y2 check box on the Auto Configure window will configure only the Y2 signals from each selected data file.

Url.Title: Example of Markers
Url.Abstract: Example of Markers

Url.Title: Example of Parts of a Graph
Url.Abstract: Example of Parts of a Graph

Url.Title: Example of Parts of a Spreadsheet
Url.Abstract: Example of Parts of a Spreadsheet

Url.Title: Legend Example
Url.Abstract: Legend Example The example below shows a legend with a border and custom text, positioned at 0.50 X axis, 0.50 Y axis, vertical center and horizontal center.

Url.Title: Example of Stacked Axes
Url.Abstract: Example of Stacked Axes

Url.Title: Example of Symbols in Curves
Url.Abstract: Example of Symbols in Curves

Url.Title: Heat of Fusion
Url.Abstract: Heat of Fusion Heat of Fusion is defined as the amount of heat required to melt one gram of solid at its melting point with no change in temperature. Usually expressed in J/g. The molar heat of fusion is the amount of heat required to melt one mole of a solid at its melting point with no change in temperature and is usually expressed in kJ/mol.

Url.Title: Lists for Step Change Between
Url.Abstract: Lists for Step Change Between Use this list to select how you want the step change (height) to be determined in step transition calculations. The step change is calculated as the change in the Y-axis between the two choices made on the Analysis Options  Step/Change Page. Choose from the following:

Url.Title: List Weight
Url.Abstract: List Weight Applicable to DSC-TGA Mode SDT Files Only. Use the Weight list to choose from different weight options that will be applied to peak integration analyses.

Url.Title: List Calculate Peak Onset Versus
Url.Abstract: List Calculate Peak Onset Versus Use this list to choose whether you want the program to calculate and display the peak onset during peak integrations and to select the variable desired.

Url.Title: List Color
Url.Abstract: List Color Use this list to select the color that you want to apply to the selected item.

Url.Title: List Colors Exported
Url.Abstract: List Colors Exported Select one of the following color combinations to apply when exporting a plot: All Colors  All of the colors shown on the monitor will be exported.

Url.Title: List Color Schemes
Url.Abstract: List Color Schemes Select the desired color scheme from the drop-down list. This scheme will provide color settings for each item shown on the window. To change a color, select the desired color for that item from its associated drop-down list.

Url.Title: List Curves to Delete
Url.Abstract: List Curves to Delete Use this list to check the curves that you want to remove from the curve overlay.

Url.Title: Cycle List
Url.Abstract: Cycle List This list displays the cycles contained in the data file. Cycles are defined by any breaks in the data (data on/off regions) or by gas switch and event markers, if they are enabled on the Main Options - Data Page. When cycles are deselected they are marked as "invalid data," but the data is still retained in memory. Enabling a deselected cycle does not reread the data file.

Url.Title: List Directory
Url.Abstract: List Directory Use this list to select a particular directory located on the selected drive.

Url.Title: List Drive
Url.Abstract: List Drive Use this list to select a particular drive located on your system.

Url.Title: Frequency/Amplitude/Location List
Url.Abstract: This list displays the frequencies, amplitudes, or locations contained in the data file.

Url.Title: Grid Type List
Url.Abstract: Grid Type List Select the desired grid type for the axis from the drop-down list. You can choose from no grid, grid lines at labeled tick marks only (those labeled with a number value), or grid lines at each tick mark displayed.

Url.Title: List HPGL Type
Url.Abstract: List HPGL Type Select the type of HPGL that you want to use for your export file format. Choose from ASCII only or UC symbols.

Url.Title: List Label Peak with Maximum
Url.Abstract: List Label Peak with Maximum Use this list to choose whether you want the program to calculate and display the peak maximum and to select the variable desired.

Url.Title: Other Language List
Url.Abstract: Other Language List Select an alternate localization language. A number of standard languages are installed along with the Universal Analysis program. If the language you want does not appear in the list then you must first add the language using the Language Add Button.

Url.Title: Line Type List
Url.Abstract: Line Type List Select the desired line type for the current Y-axis curve from the drop-down list.

Url.Title: Menu Item List
Url.Abstract: Menu Items List Check the menu items in this scrollable list that you want to display in the pop-up menu that appears when you click the right mouse button.

Url.Title: List Metafile Type
Url.Abstract: List Metafile Type Select the type of Metafile that you want to use for your export file format. Choose from Enhanced (EMF) or Windows (WMF) type.

Url.Title: List for Midpoint At
Url.Abstract: List for Midpoint At Select one of the following methods to be used in determining the midpoint in step transition analyses:

Url.Title: List Multiline
Url.Abstract: List Multiline Select a line type from each drop-down list to apply to the corresponding plot curve. You can define up to six line types. If more than six cycles exist in the data, the line types are repeated.

Url.Title: Multiplexed Signal Table List
Url.Abstract: Multiplexed Signal Table List Choose either Vertical or Horizontal from the multiplexed signal table drop-down list to display the multiplex values within the legend.

Url.Title: List Multiplex Values
Url.Abstract: List Multiplex Values Use this drop-down list to select from the available multiplexed (frequency or amplitude) values in the file.

Url.Title: List Open File Text
Url.Abstract: List Open File Text This pane displays the selected information that is available in the file. The amount of information displayed here depends upon the state of the checkboxes above this area.

Url.Title: List Other Resolution
Url.Abstract: List Other Resolution Click on the arrow to the right of the drop-down list to select the numeric resolution criteria for result values other than time or temperature. For example, if you choose "2 significant figures" from the list, a result value such as 266.1 J/g will be changed to 270 J/g.

Url.Title: List Output Signals
Url.Abstract: List Output Signals Use this list to check the output signals that will be exported in your file.

Url.Title: Symbol Differentiator List (Curve Overlay Options - Auto Page)
Url.Abstract: Symbol Differentiator List (Curve Overlay Options - Auto Page) Select the differentiator to be used for symbol designation from the drop-down list.

Url.Title: List Line Type
Url.Abstract: List Line Type Use this list to select the line type that you want to apply to the curve. See also:

Url.Title: Bitmap Pixel Format List
Url.Abstract: Bitmap Pixel Format List Select the format to be used for the exported bitmap file. Choose from the following:

Url.Title: List Axis
Url.Abstract: List Axis Select the desired axis for the purity results from the drop-down list.

Url.Title: List Project
Url.Abstract: List Project Select the project that the record will be saved to. This project list contains the Integrity projects that the person currently logged into the database has the right to access. If the list does not contain the desired project, check with the System Manager to obtain rights to that project.

Url.Title: List Result Values
Url.Abstract: List Result Values Check the items you wish to display in your results reports. To select all of the result values in the list, click the All button. To uncheck every result value in the list, click the None button.

Url.Title: List Select Files
Url.Abstract: List Select Files Use this list to check the data files containing the curves that you want to include in your curve overlay configuration. This list shows the currently open data files.

Url.Title: List Select Signal
Url.Abstract: List Select Signal Use this list to select the signal that you want to display in the curve overlay.

Url.Title: List Size
Url.Abstract: List Size Use this drop-down list to select from a list of point sizes that will be applied to the PRINTED annotation text. The size of the annotation on the monitor will not be affected.

Url.Title: List Special Area Type
Url.Abstract: List Special Area Type Click on the desired item in the drop-down list from the following: This is used to compare results with a standard material. You can change any of the numbers in the equation to tailor it to your needs. You can also type in a label of up to 20 characters with the reported value.

Url.Title: List Special Area Type - General Equation
Url.Abstract: List Special Area Type - General Equation If you select General equation from the drop-down list, when you perform a peak equation integration, a value is automatically calculated using the following equation:

Url.Title: List Special Area Type - Heat Per Mole
Url.Abstract: List Special Area Type - Heat Per Mole See also: Analysis Options - Special Area Page.

Url.Title: List Special Area Type - No Area
Url.Abstract: List Special Area Type - No Area When you select No area from the drop-down list, no special calculations using area are performed.

Url.Title: List Special Area Type - Percent Crystallinity
Url.Abstract: List Special Area Type - Percent Crystallinity Percent crystallinity is available for DSC data files only. If you select Percent crystallinity from the drop-down list, the percent crystallinity (%Cr) is calculated using the following equation:

Url.Title: List Special Area Type - Percent Cure
Url.Abstract: List Special Area Type - Percent Cure Percent cure is available for DSC data files only. If you select Percent cure from the drop-down list, the percent cure (%c) is calculated using the following equation:

Url.Title: Symbol Differentiator List
Url.Abstract: Symbol Differentiator List Select the differentiator to be used for symbol designation from the drop-down list.

Url.Title: Symbol Spacing List
Url.Abstract: Symbol Spacing List Select the spacing to be used between symbols on the curve from the drop-down list.

Url.Title: List Symbol for Curve
Url.Abstract: List Symbol for Curve Select the symbol to be used for the selected curve from the drop-down list of symbol types.

Url.Title: Symbol Type List
Url.Abstract: Symbol Type List Choose the type of symbol that will be displayed on the curve from the drop-down list. You can choose from:

Url.Title: List Temperature Resolution
Url.Abstract: List Temperature Resolution Click on the arrow to the right of the drop-down list to select the numeric resolution criteria for temperature result values. For example, if you choose "2 significant figures" from the list, a time result value such as 10.95 degrees will be changed to 11 degrees.

Url.Title: List Time Resolution
Url.Abstract: List Time Resolution Click on the arrow to the right of the drop-down list to select the numeric resolution criteria for time result values. For example, if you choose "2 significant figures" from the list, a time result value such as 10.95 min will be changed to 11 min.

Url.Title: Buttons List
Url.Abstract: Buttons List Check the name of the functions that you want to be displayed as buttons in the tool bar at the top of the main window each time the TA Instruments Universal Analysis program is opened. The name of the button corresponds to the menu item performing the same function.

Url.Title: List X Axis
Url.Abstract: List X Axis Select the signal to plot on the X axis of the humidity results plot.

Url.Title: List Y Axis
Url.Abstract: List Y Axis Select the signal to plot on axis Y1 of the humidity results plot. If a fitted line or curve is selected for plotting on axis Y4, then Y-axis also selects the name of this signal, with the word "Fit" preceding the name.

Url.Title: Melting Temperature
Url.Abstract: Melting Temperature Melting temperature is defined as the point at which the crystals of a pure substance are in equilibrium with the liquid phase at atmospheric pressure. This point is commonly referred to as melting point when a substance is approaching it from its solid state and is referred to as freezing point when a substance is approaching it from its liquid state.

Url.Title: Enter Limits
Url.Abstract: Enter Limits Use the Enter Limits menu option to select points for the new analysis range. 1. Select Enter Limits from the Analyze/Analysis Range menu. Markers will be displayed on the graph.

Url.Title: Select Cycle
Url.Abstract: Select Cycle Use the Select Cycle option to segregate data using the cycle markers contained in the data file. (See the online manual accompanying the instrument control program for information on creating methods that will add cycle markers to your data.)

Url.Title: Select Multiplex (Frequency or Amplitude)
Url.Abstract: Select Multiplex (Frequency or Amplitude) Use the Select Frequency option to separate the data according to a chosen frequency. This option is very useful when performing a function on an individual frequency.

Url.Title: Analyze Humidity
Url.Abstract: Analyze Humidity See also:

Url.Title: Delete Peak
Url.Abstract: Delete Peak Use the Delete Peak option to delete the results of a selected peak integration so that you can reanalyze the peak without deleting all of the results. If the deleted peak is a tangent or perpendicular drop subpeak, its area is returned to the peak that was subdivided. If the deleted peak contains any subpeaks, they too are deleted.

Url.Title: Extrapolated
Url.Abstract: Extrapolated Use the Extrapolated option to perform a peak integration using an extrapolated baseline.

Url.Title: Linear
Url.Abstract: Linear Use the Linear option to perform a peak integration using a linear baseline. A linear baseline is defined as a straight line drawn between the selected start and stop limits. It is used when the baseline varies directly (linearly) with time.

Url.Title: Perpendicular Drop
Url.Abstract: Perpendicular Drop After you have performed at least one peak integration on a curve, the Perpendicular Drop option becomes available when you reselect Integrate Peak from the Analyze menu.

Url.Title: Running Integral
Url.Abstract: Running Integral Use the Running Integral option to graph the integral of the data based on peak integration. This analysis is useful when you want to determine the area under a peak or the ratio of different materials within a sample. For example, in TGA, this function is valuable for determining the relative amounts of evolved gases in a material. In DSC, it can be used to calculate the percent composition of polymer blends.

Url.Title: Sigmoidal Horizontal
Url.Abstract: Sigmoidal Horizontal A sigmoidal baseline is an s-shaped line that changes in level and/or slope before or after a peak. It is used to compensate for the change in baseline that occurs during a transition; the baseline is adjusted for the fraction reacted (alpha) versus time.

Url.Title: Sigmoidal Tangent
Url.Abstract: Sigmoidal Tangent A sigmoidal baseline is an s-shaped line that changes in level and/or slope before or after a peak. It is used to compensate for the change in baseline that occurs during a transition; the baseline is adjusted for the fraction reacted (alpha) versus time.

Url.Title: Tangent
Url.Abstract: Tangent After you have performed at least one peak integration on a curve, the Tangent option becomes available when you reselect Integrate Peak from the Analyze menu.

Url.Title: Graphic Finish
Url.Abstract: Graphic Finish Use the Graphic Finish option to select an ash-free final weight using a marker to choose a corresponding X-axis point (temperature or time). The modified sample weight is considered the difference between the chosen point and the stop point.

Url.Title: Graphic Limits
Url.Abstract: Graphic Limits Use the Graphic Limits option to enter start (100%) and final (0%) sample weights by choosing corresponding X-axis points (temperature or time) using the markers.

Url.Title: Graphic Start
Url.Abstract: Graphic Start Use the Graphic Start option to select a volatile-free start weight using a marker to choose a corresponding X-axis point (temperature or time). The modified sample weight is considered the difference between the chosen point and the stop point.

Url.Title: Manual Limits
Url.Abstract: Manual Limits Use the Manual Limits option to enter start (100%) and final (0%) sample weights directly from the keyboard using the Modified Size Limits window. The modified sample weight is the difference between these two points.

Url.Title: Adjust Arrow
Url.Abstract: Adjust Arrow Select this menu item to adjust the beginning and end points of the arrow as follows: 1. Position your cursor over the inset view window. Right click to display the pop-up menu. Click on Adjust Arrow. Markers will be displayed to indicate the beginning and end points for the arrow.

Url.Title: Adjust Region
Url.Abstract: Adjust Region Select this menu item to adjust the region on the graph to be displayed in the inset view window as follows:

Url.Title: Adjust Result
Url.Abstract: Adjust Result Use Adjust Result to adjust the analysis result. When you select this option a marker is displayed. Position the marker at the desired point on the graph, right click to display the pop-up analysis menu, and select Accept Limits. The result will be adjusted. See also: Edit/Adjust Results.

Url.Title: Adjust View
Url.Abstract: Adjust View Select this menu item to adjust the size of the inset view window as follows: 1. Position your cursor over the inset view window. Right click to display the pop-up menu. Click on Adjust View. Markers will be displayed to indicate the beginning and end points for the boundaries of the inset view window.

Url.Title: Arrowheads
Url.Abstract: Arrowheads The Arrowheads menu item is accessed by right clicking on a result label to display the pop-up menu. Arrowheads is a check item like Bold that toggles on or off with each click.

Url.Title: Bold
Url.Abstract: Bold Use this menu item to make the selected annotation text bold.

Url.Title: Border
Url.Abstract: Border Use this menu item to place a border box around the selected annotation text.

Url.Title: Color
Url.Abstract: Color Use this menu item to change the color of the selected annotation text. When you select Color from the Annotation pop-up menu, the Label Color window is displayed to allow you to select a color.

Url.Title: Copy Text
Url.Abstract: Copy Text Use Copy Text to copy the text in a result label, legend, or annotation to the clipboard for retrieval later.

Url.Title: Delete Inset
Url.Abstract: Delete Inset Select this menu item to remove the inset view window from the graph.

Url.Title: Delete Label
Url.Abstract: Delete Label Use the Delete Label menu item to remove the selected analysis label from the graph. The remainder of the associated analysis result is not affected.

Url.Title: Delete Legend
Url.Abstract: Delete Legend Use Delete Legend to delete the current legend from the plot.

Url.Title: Delete Result
Url.Abstract: Delete Result Use the Delete Result menu item to remove the associated result or annotation from the graph.

Url.Title: Edit Annotation
Url.Abstract: Edit Annotation Use the Edit Annotation menu item to make changes to the selected annotation. When you select this option, the Annotation Window is displayed.

Url.Title: Edit Inset
Url.Abstract: Edit Inset Use Edit Inset to open the Inset View dialog to allow you to edit the inset view characteristics.

Url.Title: Edit Legend
Url.Abstract: Edit Legend Use Edit Legend to open the Plot Legend window to allow you to edit the plot legend.

Url.Title: Hide Result
Url.Abstract: Hide Result Use the Hide Result menu item to hide a result without deleting it. To restore the hidden result, uncheck the Hide Results menu item in the Graph menu of the normal plot.

Url.Title: Italic
Url.Abstract: Italic Use this menu item to make the selected annotation text italicized.

Url.Title: Results on Plot
Url.Abstract: Results on Plot This menu item toggles between checked and unchecked. If checked, any analysis results contained on the graph area represented by the inset view window will be displayed on the inset view. If this is unchecked, the analysis results contained on the graph area represented by the inset view window will not be displayed on the inset view.

Url.Title: Size
Url.Abstract: Size Use this menu item to change the size of the annotation text on the PRINTED graph. When you select size from the Annotation pop-up menu, the Label Size window is displayed to allow you to select a relative size. The size of the annotation on the display will not be affected. Use the Print Preview window to observe the effect of the label size change on the exported plot.

Url.Title: Transparent
Url.Abstract: Transparent Use this menu item to make the background of the selected annotation text transparent.

Url.Title: Copy
Url.Abstract: Copy Use this function to copy the selected (highlighted) data value(s) in the spreadsheet view to the clipboard for retrieval either at another place in the Universal Analysis program or retrieval in another application. Use the Paste function to retrieve the copied information.

Url.Title: Edit Cycle List
Url.Abstract: Edit Cycle List Use this menu item to select the cycles for plotting from the list of those contained in the data file. The list of cycles is displayed on the Data Cycle Selection Window.

Url.Title: All
Url.Abstract: All Use the All option to delete all of the current analysis results from the plot.

Url.Title: Axis-1,2,3.
Url.Abstract: Axis-1,2,3. Use this option to remove all of the analysis results from the selected (active) Y axis.

Url.Title: Last
Url.Abstract: Last Use the Last option to delete the last data analysis results that you performed on the plot.

Url.Title: Select
Url.Abstract: Select Use the Select option to select an analysis result for deletion. A message box will be displayed for each analysis to confirm deletion of that analysis.

Url.Title: Edit Frequency/Amplitude/Location List
Url.Abstract: Edit Frequency/Amplitude/Location List Use this menu item to select the frequencies (DMA and DEA), amplitudes (DMA), or locations (µTA) for analysis from the list of those contained in the data file. The list of frequencies, amplitudes, or locations are displayed on the Frequency/Amplitude/Location Selection Window.

Url.Title: Modify
Url.Abstract: Modify Use this function to alter the data point value of a single cell in the spreadsheet view. The data value will be modified in both the spreadsheet and graph view so that you can perform analysis functions, etc. using the modified data.

Url.Title: Select All
Url.Abstract: Select All Use this function to select (highlight) all of the data in the spreadsheet view. This allows all of the data to be copied to the clipboard for retrieval either at another place in the Universal Analysis program or retrieval in another application (such as Microsoft Excel®). Use the Copy function to copy all of the data and the Paste function to retrieve the copied information.

Url.Title: Close All Menu
Url.Abstract: Close All Menu Use the Close all option to close all of the open windows.

Url.Title: Print Preview Close
Url.Abstract: Print Preview Close Use this command to close the Print Preview window.

Url.Title: Edit Parameter Block Menu
Url.Abstract: Edit Parameter Block Menu Use the Edit Parameter Block function to open a window that allows you to edit the data file parameter block, then create and save it as a new data file. We recommend that you do not overwrite the original data file after editing the parameter block information. The altered file may not open properly if you edit the parameter block information incorrectly. If the file is not overwritten, you can go back to the original data file without a problem.

Url.Title: File and Plot Signals
Url.Abstract: File and Plot Signals Use this option to export selected signals from the data file and the plot. This function allows you to save data that has been modified with the options found in the Tools menu, as well as changes made to the Data File Information window. When you select File and Plot Signals, the Export Data File window is displayed with the signals obtained from the data file and the plot displayed and checked.

Url.Title: File Signals Only
Url.Abstract: File Signals Only Use this option to export selected signals from the data file only. When you select File Signals Only, the Export Data File window is displayed with the signals obtained from the data file displayed and checked.

Url.Title: Plot Signals Only
Url.Abstract: Plot Signals Only Use this option to export selected signals from the plot only. This function allows you to save data that has been modified with the options found in the Tools menu, as well as changes made to the Data File Information window. When you select Plot Signals Only, the Export Data File window is displayed with the signals obtained from the plot displayed and checked.

Url.Title: TTS Signals
Url.Abstract: TTS Signals Use this option to export selected DMA or DEA Time-Temperature Superposition (TTS) signals from the data file. When you select TTS Signals, the Export Data File window is displayed with the signals obtained from the data file displayed and checked, and the other proper export options selected. You can not change this information. Press Finish to specify the exported filename and location.

Url.Title: Export PDF File
Url.Abstract: Export PDF File Use the Export PDF File option to export the plot in the form of an Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF) file, which can be read by Acrobat Reader.

Url.Title: Print Preview
Url.Abstract: Print Preview Use this command to display the active document as it would appear when printed. This allows you to check the fonts and their positioning before printing. When you choose this command, the Print Preview window is displayed. You can print from this window using the File/Print command or close the window without printing it.

Url.Title: Reopen Menu
Url.Abstract: Reopen Menu Use the Reopen menu item to reopen a data file that was recently closed.

Url.Title: Auto Refresh Data
Url.Abstract: Auto Refresh Data Select this function to automatically refresh the plotted data from an active data file (real time plot), without losing completed results. The minimum amount of time between refreshes is set on the Main Options - Data Page. The default is five seconds.

Url.Title: Cursor (Data Limits)
Url.Abstract: Cursor (Data Limits) Use the Cursor option to display markers that allow you to manually select the data points that will be used for analysis.

Url.Title: Cycle (Data Limits)
Url.Abstract: Cycle (Data Limits) Use the Cycle (Limits) option to limit the data used for analysis to a specific data cycle range. This option is valid if you have any data breaks or markers in your file, these can include the following:

Url.Title: Full Range (Data Limits)
Url.Abstract: Full Range (Data Limits) Use the Full Range data limits option to use the entire range of data points that are available in the data file for analysis. This option is also used to update the data displayed from an active experiment.

Url.Title: Temperature (Data Limits)
Url.Abstract: Temperature (Data Limits) Use the Temperature Limits option to limit the data used for analysis to a specific temperature range of the data.

Url.Title: Time (Data Limits)
Url.Abstract: Time (Data Limits) Use the Time Limits option to limit the data used for analysis to a specific time range of the data.

Url.Title: Hide Results
Url.Abstract: Hide Results Click on Hide Results to check this option. Checking this item causes any results currently shown on the plot to be hidden from view, but not deleted.

Url.Title: Ignore Invalid Data Menu
Url.Abstract: Ignore Invalid Data Menu Click on Ignore Invalid Data to check this function, which is used to have the current data file plotted with a continuous curve, regardless of any invalid data points. Straight lines will be drawn between valid points. The data will be not interpolated for analysis or curve hit testing.

Url.Title: Options (Graph)
Url.Abstract: Options (Graph) Use the Options menu item to display the Graph Options window . This window will enable you to customize the axis labels, grid type, line type, color, and symbol for each curve on the graph.

Url.Title: Copy Overlay Plot (Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Copy Overlay Plot (Overlay) Use the Copy option to copy the current curve overlay plot. When you select this menu option, you are presented with a choice of overlay plots to copy. Select the desired overlay plot and a copy will be displayed.

Url.Title: Show Normal Plot (Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Show Normal Plot (Overlay) Use the Show Normal Plot option to switch the window focus to the normal plot window of the currently selected overlay curve (the curve that is numbered). To switch to a different normal plot, click on the desired overlay curve to select it, then select Graph/Overlay/Show Normal Plot.

Url.Title: Show Overlay Plot (Overlay)
Url.Abstract: Show Overlay Plot (Overlay) Use the Show Overlay Plot option to display the Curve Overlay window, if available. This window may also be displayed by selecting Curve Overlay from the Windows menu.

Url.Title: Plot Header
Url.Abstract: Plot Header Use the Plot Header option to add a text-only header to an exported or printed plot. The plot header will not be displayed on the monitor. When you select this option the Plot Header window is displayed to allow you to set up the header.

Url.Title: Plot Legend
Url.Abstract: Plot Legend Use the Plot Legend option to display the Plot Legend window , which is used to customize the legend that will be placed on the current graph.

Url.Title: Refresh Data
Url.Abstract: Refresh Data Use the Refresh Data option to redraw the data from the current data file using the last Data Limits option selected.

Url.Title: Refresh Plot
Url.Abstract: Refresh Plot Use the Refresh Plot option to redraw the plot using the current data points.

Url.Title: Signals
Url.Abstract: Signals Use the Signals menu option to access the Signal Selection Window, which allows you to choose the X- and Y-axis signals that you want to use for your graph.

Url.Title: Units
Url.Abstract: Units Use the Units option to access the Units Selection window, which allows you to choose the units that you want to use when graphing and analyzing your data files.

Url.Title: Help Menu
Url.Abstract: Help Menu Use the Help menu to access help and product information. See also:

Url.Title: Help on Print Preview Menu
Url.Abstract: Help on Print Preview Menu Use this command to display help for the Print Preview window.

Url.Title: Accept Limits
Url.Abstract: Accept Limits Use the Accept Limits function to accept the chosen data limits for analysis. The results of the analysis will be displayed on the graph.

Url.Title: Auto Limits
Url.Abstract: Auto Limits Use the Auto Limits function to store and then automatically reuse stored analysis limits. This option is good for repeating a particular analysis on similar data files and take the uncertainty factor out of trying to choose the correct analysis limits. The desired position of the cursors relative to the peak can be predetermined using the Auto Limits feature. Then when you analyze similar data files, you can recall the appropriate cursor position and perform accurate analyses quickly.

Url.Title: Cancel Pop-up Menu Item
Url.Abstract: Cancel Pop-up Menu Item Use the Cancel option to abort the operation chosen.

Url.Title: Delete
Url.Abstract: Delete Use the Delete option to remove the selected curve from the curve overlay window.

Url.Title: Manual Limits
Url.Abstract: Manual Limits Use the Manual Limits function to select limit points by entering numeric values from the keyboard. When you select this option the Manual Limits window is displayed, allowing you to enter the numerical values desired.

Url.Title: Move Down
Url.Abstract: Move Down Use the Move Down option to move the selected curve down one position.

Url.Title: Move to Bottom
Url.Abstract: Move to Bottom Use the Move to Bottom option to move the selected curve to the bottom of the list of curves.

Url.Title: Move to Top
Url.Abstract: Move to Top Use the Move to Top option to move the selected curve to the top of the list of curves.

Url.Title: Move Up
Url.Abstract: Move Up Use the Move Up option to move the selected curve up one position.

Url.Title: Point 1,2,3,4,5,6
Url.Abstract: Point 1,2,3,4,5,6 Use the Point menu items to activate the applicable marker on the graph. This allows you to more accurately position the markers for analysis. The number of points available depend upon the type of analysis and the chosen analysis options.

Url.Title: Rescale/Manual Menu
Url.Abstract: Manual Rescale Menu The Manual rescale option is used to select exact start and stop limits for the x- and y-axes to reduce or expand the graph, and to change the label and tick intervals.

Url.Title: Same Scale
Url.Abstract: Same Scale When the Same Scale option is selected, all of the axes that have the same units are rescaled to the same axis scales. The largest scale maximum and the smallest scale minimum are used for the scale limits.

Url.Title: Spreadsheet View Pop-up Signals
Url.Abstract: Spreadsheet View Pop-up Signals This list displays the signals that you have selected on the Signal Selection window (accessed by selecting Graph/Signals from the main menu). To display the data contained in the data file for that signal in the Spreadsheet View, check the signal name menu item. To remove the item from the Spreadsheet View, uncheck the signal name menu item.

Url.Title: Baseline File
Url.Abstract: Baseline File Use Baseline File to perform baseline subtraction or addition. File addition or subtraction requires the use of two data files, a sample and a baselinereference file, both obtained from the sample instrument, to create a modified sample signal(s). When you select this function, you will get a choice of the available files to be used as the baseline file. After selecting a file, the Baseline File window is displayed.

Url.Title: Desmear
Url.Abstract: Desmear Select this menu item to open the Desmear Curve window, which allows you to improve the resolution of DSC sharp melting peaks. When properly applied, this approach can generate data that matches the resolution obtained in DSC Q Series™ T4P heat flow. The desmearing routine is an offline approach and requires you to adjust a value until the desired curve shape is obtained.

Url.Title: Linear Transform - X/Y Axis
Url.Abstract: Linear Transform - X/Y Axis Use the Linear Transform/X Axis or the Linear Transform/Y Axis function to adjust the slope and/or intercept of the selected X- or Y-axis signal.

Url.Title: Remove Shifts
Url.Abstract: Remove Shifts Use the Remove Shifts function to undo any shifting or rotating of the curve. NOTE: When a linear transformation is applied to the shifted data, the function is no longer available.

Url.Title: Rotate
Url.Abstract: Rotate Use the Rotate option to take the curve and rotate it around the points chosen. Follow these steps to use this function:

Url.Title: Sensitivity
Url.Abstract: Sensitivity The Sensitivity option allows you to analyze curve sensitivity using a least-squares averaging technique.

Url.Title: Shift
Url.Abstract: Shift Use the Shift option to move the curve up or down to the position of the horizontal bar of the marker.

Url.Title: Smooth
Url.Abstract: Smooth The Smooth option allows you to smooth curves using a least-squares averaging technique. Normal curves are smoothed versus the X-axis signal, and derivative curves are smoothed versus the X-axis signal with respect to which the derivative was taken. Integral curves cannot be smoothed. We recommend that you perform smoothing before any analysis functions.

Url.Title: Autoqueue Report (View)
Url.Abstract: Autoqueue Report (View) Use the Autoqueue Report function to view the list of records contained in the autoqueue for autoanalysis. Each record is made up of the data filename, macro filename, and associated macro.

Url.Title: Autoqueue Log (Vew)
Url.Abstract: Autoqueue Log (Vew) Use the Autoqueue Log function to view the log of the results obtained during autoanalysis. Each item in the log is made up of the pass/fail message, the data filename, the macro filename, the associated macro, and a short comment.

Url.Title: Current Macro Report
Url.Abstract: Current Macro Report Use the Current Macro Report function to view the list of steps contained in the currently open macro.

Url.Title: Data Table Report
Url.Abstract: Data Table Report Use the Data Table function to display a report showing the sample information and raw data points from the data file. For multiplexed data, such as frequency or amplitude, a separate table is generated for each multiplexed value.

Url.Title: Data Table Spreadsheet
Url.Abstract: Data Table Spreadsheet Use the Data Table function to display, in your spreadsheet application, such as Microsoft Excel®, the sample information and raw data points from the data file.

Url.Title: Method Log
Url.Abstract: Method Log Use the Method Log function to view a listing of the method segments that were used to obtain the data file. Each experimental method is made up of a group of segments, which are preprogrammed instructions that are sent to the analytical instrument.

Url.Title: Parameter Block
Url.Abstract: Parameter Block Use the Parameter Block function to view a listing of the experimental parameters that were used when obtaining the data stored in the data file. When you select this item from the View menu, the Report Editor program is automatically opened, displaying the parameters and allowing you to edit and print the report using the Report Editor functions. (You may edit the text displayed in these reports, but it will be for display purposes only.)

Url.Title: Report Editor
Url.Abstract: Report Editor Use the Report Editor function to open the Report Editor program.

Url.Title: Results Options
Url.Abstract: Results Options Use the Results Options functions to open a window that allows you to individually select the types of results and options you want to display in your results report, whether it is displayed in the regular Universal Analysis report form or in a spreadsheet.

Url.Title: Results Report
Url.Abstract: Results Report Use the Results Report function to view the results of your analysis in a written report form. When you select this item from the View menu, the Report Editor program is automatically opened, displaying the analysis results and allowing you to edit and print the report using the Report Editor functions.

Url.Title: Results Spreadsheet
Url.Abstract: Results Spreadsheet Use the Results Report function to view the results of your analysis in a spreadsheet application. When you select this item from the View menu, your spreadsheet application, such as Microsoft Excel®, is automatically opened, displaying the analysis results and allowing you to edit and modify the resulting data.

Url.Title: Window Arrange Icons
Url.Abstract: Window Arrange Icons Use this command to arrange the icons for minimized windows at the bottom of the main window. If there is an open document window at the bottom of the main window, then some or all of the icons may not be visible because they will be underneath this document window.

Url.Title: Cascade Windows
Url.Abstract: Cascade Windows Use this command to arrange multiple opened windows in an overlapped fashion.

Url.Title: Window Stay on Top
Url.Abstract: Window Stay on Top Use this command to keep the Universal Analysis program window always on the top of any other opened windows.

Url.Title: Tile Windows
Url.Abstract: Tile Windows Use this command to arrange multiple opened windows in a non-overlapped fashion.

Url.Title: Accept Limits (Zoom Box)
Url.Abstract: Accept Limits (Zoom Box) Use the Accept Limits function to accept the chosen limits for expanding the curve on the current y axis. The results of the zoom function will be displayed on the graph.

Url.Title: Accept Limits All Axes (Zoom Box)
Url.Abstract: Accept Limits All Axes (Zoom Box) Use the Accept Limits All Axes function to accept the chosen limits for expanding the curves for all axes within the zoom box area. The results of the zoom function will be displayed on the graph.

Url.Title: Auto Inset View
Url.Abstract: Auto Inset View Use the Auto Inset View function to place the inset view (picture-in-picture) in the default location using the limits chosen with the zoom box function.

Url.Title: Peak Area Calculation
Url.Abstract: Peak Area Calculation In Universal Analysis the area of a peak is calculated as a running sum of trapezoidal area sections. The corner points of each trapezoid are defined by adjacent data points taken from the signal curve and the peak integration baseline. The parallel sides of each trapezoid are vertical, not perpendicular to the baseline (unless the baseline happens to be horizontal.) The first and last sections of the area sumation are defined by two area triangles. One corner of each triangle is defined by the intersection of the curve and an endpoint of the baseline. The other corners of the triangles correspond to the corners of the first and last trapezoidal sections.

Url.Title: Popup - Copy
Url.Abstract: Popup - Copy Use the Copy option to copy the information to the clipboard for retrieval by the Paste option.

Url.Title: Popup - Cut
Url.Abstract: Popup - Cut Use the Cut option to remove information and place it on the clipboard for retrieval by the Paste option.

Url.Title: Popup - Delete
Url.Abstract: Popup - Delete Use the Delete option to delete the selected information.

Url.Title: Popup Edit Text Menu
Url.Abstract: Popup Edit Text Menu Use this menu to edit text. This menu functions much like various other word processing programs and text editors, so it is probably familiar to you.

Url.Title: Popup - Paste
Url.Abstract: Popup  Paste Use the Paste option to retrieve any information placed on the clipboard.

Url.Title: Popup - Select All
Url.Abstract: Popup - Select All Use the Select All option to highlight all of the text in the current file. You can then copy it to the clipboard for retrieval or delete it, etc.

Url.Title: Popup - Undo
Url.Abstract: Popup - Undo Use the Undo option to cancel the last action performed.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Add/Subtract Operation
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Add/Subtract Operation Select the desired radio button as follows:

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Match Name/Units
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Match Name/Units Select the desired radio button as follows:

Url.Title: Area Percent (Integral Type)
Url.Abstract: Area Percent (Integral Type) Use the Area Percent radio button to take the end result of the raw integration and show the percent contribution of each peak in the selected region of the curve (assuming the selected region to be 100%). If you want to determine the percent composition of various components in a material, select the area percent option. Then, when the program finishes plotting the integral curve, use one of the Curve Value functions to mark each step of the curve with its percent contribution.

Url.Title: Radio Button Auto Limits Cursor
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Auto Limits Cursor Click on this radio button to use the exact position of the cursor (marker), which is chosen (not preset) during the analysis. This selects limits that are not related to the location of the transition.

Url.Title: Radio Button Derivative Fraction
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Derivative Fraction Click on the Derivation fraction radio button to determine the weight change using the point determined by the derivative fraction entered.

Url.Title: Radio Button Auto Limits Offset
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Auto Limits Offset Click on this radio button to set the analysis limit as an offset value relative to the current peak maximum/inflection point/onset point.

Url.Title: Radio Button Axes/Curves
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Axes/Curves Click on the Axes or Curves radio button to automatically apply the associated setting to the curve overlay axes.

Url.Title: Bitmap Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Bitmap Radio Button Click on this button to export your plot to a file using the Bitmap format. If you select this option, you must also choose a Bitmap pixel format from the drop-down list.

Url.Title: Radio Button OEM (PC-8) Character Set
Url.Abstract: Radio Button OEM (PC-8) Character Set Select this radio button to specify that all text output in the exported data file will use the OEM character set.

Url.Title: Radio Button Unicode Character Set
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Unicode Character Set Select this radio button to specify that all text output in the exported data file will use the Unicode character set.

Url.Title: Radio Button Windows (ANSI) Character Set
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Windows (ANSI) Character Set Select this radio button to specify that all text output in the exported data file will use the Windows character set.

Url.Title: Clipboard Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Clipboard Radio Button Click on this button to export the plot to the computer clipboard so that it may be pasted into other applications after export. Note that you must also select the desired formatMetafile or Bitmapbefore exporting the plot.

Url.Title: Radio Button Compatible Signals or All Signals
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Compatible Signals or All Signals Choose the signals that you wish to use in the curve overlay graph:

Url.Title: File Radio Button
Url.Abstract: File Radio Button Click on this button to export the plot to a file. If you choose the file export option, you must enter a filename or use the Browse button to locate a filename. You must also select the format for export.

Url.Title: Full Size Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Full Size Radio Button Click this button to make the exported plot the full size, as it is captured from the program.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons - Justification
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons  Justification Click on the desired radio button to select a justification option for your text.

Url.Title: Radio Button Half Minor Axis Tick
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Half Minor Axis Tick Click this radio button to position (offset) each curve on the axis positively by an amount equal to a half minor axis tick when the Auto Offset button is selected.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Horizontal
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Horizontal See also:

Url.Title: HPGL Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Click on this button to export your plot to a file using the HPGL format. If you select this option, you must also choose a HPGL symbol type from the HPGL list.

Url.Title: Integral Radio Button (Integral Type)
Url.Abstract: Integral Radio Button (Integral Type) Use the Integral radio button to plot the raw integrated data.

Url.Title: Radio Button Major Axis Tick
