Url.Abstract: Radio Button Major Axis Tick Click this radio button to position (offset) each curve on the positively axis by an amount equal to a major axis tick when the Auto Offset button is selected.

Url.Title: Metafile Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Metafile Radio Button Click on this button to export your plot to a file using the Metafile format. If you select this option, you must also choose a Metafile type from the Metafile list.

Url.Title: Radio Button Minor Axis Tick
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Minor Axis Tick Click this radio button to position (offset) each curve on the axis positively by an amount equal to a minor axis tick when the Auto Offset button is selected.

Url.Title: Radio Button Normal or Reversed
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Normal or Reversed

Url.Title: Radio Button Orientation Portrait or Landscape
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Orientation Portrait or Landscape

Url.Title: Radio Button Output Port
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Output Port Click on the radio button for the output port connected to your HPGL plotter.

Url.Title: PDF Radio Button
Url.Abstract: PDF Radio Button Click on this button to export your plot to a file using the PDF format. If you select this option, you must also choose a paper size from the drop-down list to the right.

Url.Title: Radio Button Percent of Axis Range
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Percent of Axis Range Click this radio button to position (offset) each curve on the axis by an amount equal to the percentage of the axis range entered when the Auto Offset button is selected.

Url.Title: Pixels Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Pixels Radio Button Click on this button to size the exported plot in pixels, rather than in a percentage.

Url.Title: Plotter Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Plotter Radio Button Click on this button to export the plot to a plotter. The plotter must already be configured online with your computer and connected to the Com 1 port.

Url.Title: Radio Button Orientation Portrait or Landscape - Plot
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Orientation Portrait or Landscape - Plot

Url.Title: Printer Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Printer Radio Button Click on this button to export the plot to a printer. The printer must already be configured online with your computer.

Url.Title: Reduction Radio Button
Url.Abstract: Reduction Radio Button Click this button to reduce the exported plot by the percent that you enter in the Height and Width fields.

Url.Title: Radio Button Orientation Portrait or Landscape - Reports
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Orientation Portrait or Landscape - Reports NOTE: The report orientation applies to the Report Editor program, The Custom Report Editor program, and the Macro Editor.

Url.Title: Scale Bar Direction Radio Buttons
Url.Abstract: Scale Bar Direction Radio Buttons Select the radio button for the orientation of the scale bar on the graph.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Time /Temperature Base
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Time /Temperature Base Select the desired radio button as follows:

Url.Title: Radio Button Up or Down
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Up or Down Select the direction to plot your heat flow or temperature difference data for RMX-created data files only.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Vertical
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Vertical See also:

Url.Title: Radio Button Y1 Axis
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Y1 Axis Click this button to configure the Y1 axis for curve overlay. Curves added to this axis must have the same units and can be used only once.

Url.Title: Radio Button Y2 Axis
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Y2 Axis Click this button to configure the Y2 axis for curve overlay. Curves added to this axis must have the same units and can be used only once.

Url.Title: Radio Button Y3 Axis
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Y3 Axis Click this button to configure the Y3 axis for curve overlay. Curves added to this axis must have the same units and can be used only once.

Url.Title: Radio Button Y4 Axis
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Y4 Axis Click this button to configure the Y4 axis for curve overlay. Curves added to this axis must have the same units and can be used only once.

Url.Title: Y-Axis Radio Buttons
Url.Abstract: Y-Axis Radio Buttons Click on the Y-axis button that designates which Y-axis curve you want to set up using the Graph Options window. Then proceed to select the desired settings.

Url.Title: Running Area Baselines
Url.Abstract: Running Area Baselines Click on the desired type of baseline that will be used for running integral analysis.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons - Data Compaction Options
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons - Data Compaction Options Choose from one of the following ways to handle data compaction for your files.

Url.Title: Data Compression Options
Url.Abstract: Data Compression Options Select a radio button as follows:

Url.Title: Radio Buttons - Date Format
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons - Date Format Choose from one of the following ways to set up the date displayed by the program (e.g., displayed on the printed graph and in the parameter block information).

Url.Title: Excluded Points Options
Url.Abstract: Excluded Points Options Select one of the radio buttons as follows: Use this option to remove the selected data from the graph. When you click on this option on the Exclude Data window, it results in the removal of the selected data range from the graph, creating a discontinuous data region between the selection limits. This option provides a way to create very small data breaks between thermal cycles, which allows each cycle to be distinguished using a different symbol. (See Graph Options.)

Url.Title: Radio Buttons MDSC Phase Correction
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons MDSC Phase Correction Click on the desired radio button as follows:

Url.Title: Radio Group Method Log Date-and-Time Stamp
Url.Abstract: Radio Group Method Log Date-and-Time Stamp Choose the radio button for the option that will be displayed in square brackets at the beginning of each line of the method log. The method log must contain time and stamp information for the date and time to be displayed. If no time stamp information is available, empty brackets, [], will be displayed. Data files created with instrument software released prior to June 2002 do not contain method log time stamp information.

Url.Title: Radio Button Group Export Data File
Url.Abstract: Radio Button Group Export Data File Each radio button used for the Export Data File window is explained as follows:

Url.Title: Radio Buttons - Time of Day Format
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons - Time of Day Format Choose from one of the following ways to set up the data file time displayed by the program (e.g., displayed on the printed graph and in the parameter block information).

Url.Title: R Squared
Url.Abstract: R Squared R² (R-squared) is a mathematical term describing how much error is attributable to the regression model. R² is defined as one minus a ratio of sums. The ratio numerator is the sum of the squared differences between the actual data and the model. The ratio denominator is the sum of the squared differences between the actual data and the mean.

Url.Title: Smoothing Calculation
Url.Abstract: Smoothing Calculation In Universal Analysis the smoothed value of a signal is computed by evaluating a point on a fitted line at each data point along the curve. The fit is made using the method of least squares. The region over which the fit is made is a window of data points equal to the width of the signal-smoothing window (See Tools/Smooth).

Url.Title: Spreadsheet View Pop-up Menu
Url.Abstract: Spreadsheet View Pop-up Menu When the Graph/Spreadsheet function has been selected and the data is displayed in a spreadsheet format, you can right-click to reveal a pop-up menu to allow you to edit the spreadsheet.

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Weight Group
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Weight Group

Url.Title: About Universal Analysis Window
Url.Abstract: About Universal Analysis Window This window displays the copyright notice, software key information, version number, and license information for your copy of Thermal AdvantageUniversal Analysis.

Url.Title: Add Overlay Curves Window
Url.Abstract: Add Overlay Curves Window Use this window to add curves to your curve overlay configuration. Each curve may be selected from a different data file, with all curves being selected from up to ten different data files. Curves added to the same axis must contain the same units.

Url.Title: Analysis Log Comment Window
Url.Abstract: Analysis Log Comment Window This window is used to add a comment to the analysis log for the current file. The comment appears in the analysis log and is identified by a " / / " in front of the entered text. To view the analysis log, select View/Analysis Log from the menu.

Url.Title: Analysis Options - Onset/Peak Integration Page
Url.Abstract: Analysis Options - Onset/Peak Integration Page Use this page to set up the parameters for the program to use when you perform a onset or peak integration analysis.

Url.Title: Analysis Options - Other Page
Url.Abstract: Analysis Options - Other Page Use this page to select special additional analysis parameters. 1. For TMA Files Only: Enter the desired Alpha at a point smoothing width. The number entered here will result in the logical smoothing of the data to the specified width.

Url.Title: Analysis Options - Resolution Page
Url.Abstract: Analysis Options - Resolution Page Use this page to set the numeric resolution of all result values that are displayed on the plot and in the reports generated by the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Analysis Options - Special Area Page
Url.Abstract: Analysis Options - Special Area Page Use this page to select a special area calculation, if desired. Special area calculations are additional analyses performed when you integrate a peak.

Url.Title: Analysis Options - Step/Change Page
Url.Abstract: Analysis Options - Step/Change Page Use this page to set up the parameters for the program to use when you perform a step transition, glass transition, or signal change analysis.

Url.Title: Annotation Window
Url.Abstract: Annotation Window Use the Annotation window to edit or place text on your graph as follows: 1. Enter or edit the desired text in the Text box. The maximum number of characters in a single line is 60. The maximum number of lines allowed is 20. NOTE:Text may be copied to or pasted from clipboard by clicking the right mouse button in Annotation text box and selecting the desired function or by typing the appropriate control key. (See also:Edit Text pop-up menu.)

Url.Title: Auto Onset Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Auto Onset Limits Window Use this window to determine the way analysis limits are chosen for repeat analyses on materials that you expect to exhibit similar thermal plots. This option is particularly useful when used in combination with the Autoanalysis option. The Auto Onset Limits window is available and can be displayed when you perform an onset point analysis.

Url.Title: Auto Oxidation Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Auto Oxidation Limits Window Use this window to determine the way analysis limits are chosen for repeat analyses on materials that you expect to exhibit similar thermal plots. This option is particularly useful when used in combination with the Autoanalysis option. The Auto Oxidation Limits window is available and can be displayed when you perform an oxidation time or temperature analysis.

Url.Title: Auto Peak Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Auto Peak Limits Window Use this window to determine the way analysis limits are chosen for repeat analyses on materials that you expect to exhibit similar thermal plots. This option is particularly useful when used in combination with the Autoanalysis option. The Auto Peaks Limits window is available and can be displayed when you perform either linear peak integration or sigmoidal horizontal peak integration.

Url.Title: Auto Signal Change Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Auto Signal Change Limits Window Use this window to determine the way analysis limits are chosen for repeat analyses on materials that you expect to exhibit similar thermal plots. This option is particularly useful when used in combination with the Autoanalysis option. The Auto Signal Change Limits window is available and can be displayed when you perform a signal change analysis.

Url.Title: Auto Step Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Auto Step Limits Window Use this window to determine the way analysis limits are chosen for repeat analyses on materials that you expect to exhibit similar thermal plots. This option is particularly useful when used in combination with the Autoanalysis option. The Auto Step Limits window is available and can be displayed when you perform either step or glass transition.

Url.Title: Auto Weight Change Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Auto Weight Change Limits Window Use this window to determine the way analysis limits are chosen for repeat analyses on materials that you expect to exhibit similar thermal plots. This option is particularly useful when used in combination with the Autoanalysis option. The Auto Weight Change Limits window is available and can be displayed when you perform a TGA weight change analysis.

Url.Title: Baseline File Window
Url.Abstract: Baseline File Window Use Baseline File to perform baseline subtraction or addition. Follow the steps below to either subtract or add the baseline.

Url.Title: Curve Overlay Options - Auto Page
Url.Abstract: Curve Overlay Options - Auto Page Use this page to set up the Auto Line, Auto Color, and Auto Offset buttons shown on the Curve page and to set up the similar settings on the Auto Configure window. The settings shown on this page will be used when you click on those buttons.

Url.Title: Curve Overlay Options - Axes Page
Url.Abstract: Curve Overlay Options - Axes Page This page displays the axes that have been set up for curve overlay using the Curves Page. Use this page to customize the axis labels that will be displayed on the curve overlay window.

Url.Title: Curve Overlay Options - Curves Page
Url.Abstract: Curve Overlay Options - Curves Page Performing a curve overlay operation lets you combine curves from several different experiments or experimental techniques to provide a visual comparison of the data. This will allow you to "overlay" the curves on one window and position the graphs to display the data in a manner that enables you to emphasize important aspects of the data. Up to four individual y-axes may be used, containing up to ten curves, each of common units. You can create a total of 20 different overlay plot windows.

Url.Title: Curve Overlay Options - Grid Page
Url.Abstract: Curve Overlay Options - Grid Page Use this page to select the grid that can be used for each axis. 1. Click on the radio button to choose the desired Y axis that will display the grid.

Url.Title: Curve Overlay Options - Legend Page
Url.Abstract: Curve Overlay Options - Legend Page Use this window to customize the legend that appears on the curve overlay window. An entry in the legend appears for each curve that is displayed in the overlay graph. Follow these steps to choose what will appear in the legend:

Url.Title: Curve Overlay Options - Plot Heading Page
Url.Abstract: Curve Overlay Options - Plot Heading Page Use this window to customize the plot header that will be placed on the curve overlay graph. Follow these steps:

Url.Title: Curve Symbol Window
Url.Abstract: Curve Symbol Window Use this window, accessed by clicking in the symbols column of the Curves Page, to select the symbols to be used for the curves.

Url.Title: Cycle Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Cycle Limits Window Use this window to limit the data used for analysis to a specific data cycle range. This option is valid if you have any data breaks or markers in your file, these can include the following:

Url.Title: Data Cycle Selection Window
Url.Abstract: Data Cycle Selection Window Use this window to check the cycles that you want to use for plotting from the list of those contained in the data file. Cycles are defined by any breaks in the data (data on/off regions) or by gas switch and event markers, if they are enabled on the Main Options - Data Page. When cycles are deselected they are marked as "invalid data," but the data is still retained in memory. Enabling a deselected cycle does not reread the data file.

Url.Title: Data Compression Window
Url.Abstract: Data Compression Window Use this window to choose the data compaction each time the program opens a large data file that exceeds the data buffer size and must be compacted.

Url.Title: Data Cycle Window
Url.Abstract: Data Cycle Window Use the Data Cycle window to choose data for segregation using the cycle markers contained in the data file. (See the online manual accompanying Thermal Advantage Instrument Control for information on creating methods that will add cycle markers to your data.)

Url.Title: Data File Information
Url.Abstract: Data File Information Use this window to verify the information contained in the current data file. Some of the information is not editable here since it is a fixed part of the data file. To change the editable information, follow the instructions below:

Url.Title: Data Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Data Limits Window Use the Data Limits window to select from three options. These allow you to use the entire data file for analysis, or to place constraints on the amount and type of data.

Url.Title: Data Multiplex Window
Url.Abstract: Data Multiplex Window Use the Data Multiplex (Frequency or Amplitude) window to separate the data according to a chosen frequency or amplitude. This option is very useful when performing a function on an individual mulitplexed value.

Url.Title: Data Table Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Data Table Limits Window Use the Data Table Limits window to select the range of data that you want output to the data table report or data table spreadsheet. This lets you restrict the data to a particular range and set the spacing between the reported values.

Url.Title: Delete Overlay Curves Window
Url.Abstract: Delete Overlay Curves Window Use this window, accessed by clicking the Delete Curves button on the Curves Page, to delete selected curves from the overlay graphing for the selected Y axis. The overlay axis and its label are shown at the top of the window.

Url.Title: Desmear Curve Window
Url.Abstract: Desmear Curve Window The Desmear Curve window allows you to improve the resolution of DSC sharp melting peaks. When properly applied, this approach can generate data that matches the resolution obtained in DSC Q Series T4P heat flow. The desmearing routine is an offline approach and requires you to adjust a value until the desired curve shape is obtained.

Url.Title: Edit Custom Symbol List Window
Url.Abstract: Edit Custom Symbol List Window Use this window to select the symbols that you want to apply to your curves. The symbols and font that you select here will be applied each time you apply the custom symbols to your graph.

Url.Title: Exclude Data Window
Url.Abstract: Exclude Data Window Use this window to choose the desired option to be used when the program excludes the selected data region. Each option produces a different result.

Url.Title: Export Data File Window
Url.Abstract: Export Data File Window Use this window to choose signals that will be exported to one of the following types of files:

Url.Title: Export Plot Window
Url.Abstract: Export Plot Window When you want to use a plot for another application or have it printed, use the Export Plot option to access this window. You can exclude certain parts of the plot, if desired, so that they do not appear in the exported plot.

Url.Title: File Information Window
Url.Abstract: File Information Window Use the File Information Window to modify the parameters on the Data File Information Window. If only text items are changed, the data in memory is not reloaded (i.e., current analyses are not lost). If any other items are changed, the data is reread from the file so the new values (e.g.,size, cell constant) can be applied. These changes are not saved to the original data file.

Url.Title: Font Window
Url.Abstract: Font Window Use this window to set up the font, font style, font size, and type of script used. Follow these steps to set up the font characteristics:

Url.Title: Frequency/Amplitude/Force/Stress/Location Selection Window
Url.Abstract: Frequency/Amplitude/Force/Stress/Location Selection Window Use this window to check the frequencies (DMA and DEA), amplitudes (DMA), forces (DMA), stresses (DMA), or locations (µTA) that you want to use for analysis from the list of those contained in the data file.

Url.Title: Humidity Analysis Options - BET Analysis
Url.Abstract: Humidity Analysis Options - BET Analysis Use this page to set up the default parameters for the program to use when you perform the TGA Humidity BET analysis.

Url.Title: Humidity Analysis Options - GAB Analysis
Url.Abstract: Humidity Analysis Options - GAB Analysis Use this page to set up the default parameters for the program to use when you perform the TGA Humidity GAB analysis.

Url.Title: Humidity Analysis Options - Sorption Isotherm
Url.Abstract: Humidity Analysis Options - Sorption Isotherm Use this page to set up the default parameters for the program to use when you perform the TGA Humidity Sorption Isotherm analysis.

Url.Title: Insert Data File Parameters Window
Url.Abstract: Insert Data File Parameters Window Use this window to select data file parameter block information for insertion into your annotation as follows:

Url.Title: Inset View Window
Url.Abstract: Inset View Window Use this window to customize the appearance of the inset view as follows: 1. Check the items that you want to appear on the inset view window:

Url.Title: Instrument Parameters Window - DMA
Url.Abstract: Instrument Parameters Window - DMA The DMA Instrument Parameters window is used to enter the desired Poissons ratio.

Url.Title: Instrument Parameters Window - DMA 983
Url.Abstract: Instrument Parameters Window - DMA 983 Use this window to enter the instrument parameters that are used for the DMA 983 data analysis.

Url.Title: Instrument Parameters Window - MDSC
Url.Abstract: Instrument Parameters Window  MDSC® Use this window to enter the instrument parameters that are used when performing an MDSC® phase correction procedure. Click here for details on how to perform MDSC® phase correction.

Url.Title: Integral Type Window
Url.Abstract: Integral Type Window Use this window to select the following: Click on the desired option, select click on the OK button.

Url.Title: Integration Weight Selection Window
Url.Abstract: Integration Weight Selection Window Use this window to select the desired weight to be used when performing peak integration analysis for non-weight signals plotted from the DSC-TGA data file.

Url.Title: Label Color Window
Url.Abstract: Label Color Window Use the Label Color window to choose a color for the annotation text you have already created.

Url.Title: Label Point Window
Url.Abstract: Label Point Window Use this window to label your curve value with one or more of the following items. Check the desired option(s), then click the OK button.

Url.Title: Label Resolution Window
Url.Abstract: Label Resolution Window Use this window to set the numeric resolution of an individual result value that is displayed on the plot and in the reports generated by the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Label Size Window
Url.Abstract: Label Size Window Use the Label Size window to choose a point size for the annotation text you have already created. The size change will not affect the size of the annotation text displayed on the monitorit will affect the size of annotation text on the PRINTED graph.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Color Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Color Page Use this window to set up the colors that you want to use as your default settings when you are using the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Data Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Data Page Use this window to set up the way that your data files will be presented each time the Universal Analysis program is opened. You can set these options as desired and they will be applied each time you open the program.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Directories Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Directories Page Use this window to set up the file directories (folders) that you want to use as your default settings when you are using the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Export Plot Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Export Plot Page Use this window to set up the plot items that you want to include as your defaults when you are exporting a plot, either as a file to or a printer. See Export Plot Window for more information on exporting plots.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Font Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Font Page Use the Font page of the Main Options window to set up the fonts that appear on the printed curve. Changing fonts here will not affect the graphs displayed on your monitor. To check the size and position of the text on the graph before it is printed, use the File/Print Preview option.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Other Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window - Other Page Use this window to set up some miscellaneous options that you may want to use as your default settings when you are using the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Pop-Up Menu Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Pop-Up Menu Page Use the Pop-Up Menu page of the Main Options window to set up the items that you want to display every time the pop-up menu is displayed by clicking the right mouse button.

Url.Title: Main Options Window - Tool Bar Page
Url.Abstract: Main Options Window  Tool Bar Page Use the Tool Bar page of the Main Options window to set up the tool bar icons that you want to display every time the Universal Analysis program is opened.

Url.Title: Manual Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Manual Limits Window Use the Manual Limits window to enter numeric values from the keyboard for the data limit points needed for the analysis function chosen. This window can display from one to six points depending upon the analysis and the analysis options chosen for that analysis function.

Url.Title: Modified Size Window
Url.Abstract: Modified Size Window This is a read-only window that displays the start and final weights that you selected, along with the modified sample size that will be used for analysis.

Url.Title: Modified Size Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Modified Size Limits Window Use the Modified Size Limits window to enter the start and final sample weights as follows:

Url.Title: Modify Data Window
Url.Abstract: Modify Data Window Use this window to alter the data point value of a single cell in the spreadsheet view. (NOTE: This option is not available if multiple cells are selected.) The data value will be modified in both the spreadsheet and graph view so that you can perform analysis functions, etc. using the modified data.

Url.Title: Molecular Weight Window
Url.Abstract: Molecular Weight Window This window is displayed when the box for Use known molecular weight is not checked on the Purity Analysis Options - Purity Calculations Page or on the Humidity Analysis Options - Sorption Isotherm Page when moisture content in moles is selected for the Y-Axis.

Url.Title: Open/Save/Save As/Load File Window
Url.Abstract: Open/Save/Save As/Load File Window Use this window to locate and open, save, or load a file. 1. Select the arrow to the right of Look in: to display all the folders on your system. Optional: You can directly type the full path and filename of the desired file in the File Name field and skip to step 5.

Url.Title: Overlay Auto Configure Window
Url.Abstract: Overlay Auto Configure Window Use this window to select options that the program will automatically configure for you and will be used to create a curve overlay graph. You can use the Auto Configure window to set up a curve overlay graph initially (using the program-optimized settings), then use the Graph/Overlay/Manual SetUp function to refine your overlay graph.

Url.Title: Oxidation Temperature Window
Url.Abstract: Oxidation Temperature Window Use this window to enter the signal threshold, which is the point on the curve at which deviation from the baseline begins.

Url.Title: Oxidation Time Window
Url.Abstract: Oxidation Time Window Use this window to enter the following two parameters: 1. Enter the signal threshold value in W/g.

Url.Title: Print Preview Window
Url.Abstract: Print Preview Window Use this window to view the current graph as it would appear when printed. The menus shown on this window allow you to perform several functions:

Url.Title: Purity Analysis Options - Partial Area
Url.Abstract: Purity Analysis Options - Partial Area Use this page to set up the default parameters for the program to use when you perform the DSC Purity analysis.

Url.Title: Purity Analysis Options - Purity Calculation
Url.Abstract: Purity Analysis Options - Purity Calculation Use this page to set up the default parameters for the program to use when you perform the DSC Purity analysis.

Url.Title: Purity Analysis Options - Results Label
Url.Abstract: Purity Analysis Options - Results Label Use this page to set up the results labels that will be displayed when you perform the DSC Purity analysis and display the results.

Url.Title: Purity Analysis Options  Results Plot
Url.Abstract: Purity Analysis Options  Results Plot Use this page to set up the default parameters for the program to use when you perform the DSC Purity analysis and display the results plots. Five checkbox options are displayed. These deal with the plot options that can be displayed along with the heat flow curve.

Url.Title: Report Editor Program
Url.Abstract: Report Editor Program The Report Editor program is an independent program contained within Universal Analysis that is used to display and print reports. (You may edit the text displayed in these reports, but it will be for display purposes only.) It can also be used as a text editor to write and print your own text report files.

Url.Title: Reset Size Window
Url.Abstract: Reset Size Window This window is displayed when the Reset Size function is selected from the Analyze menu. The new size is automatically calculated from the accepted marker position and entered into the New Size entry field. The Original size from the data file is displayed above.

Url.Title: Result Options Window
Url.Abstract: Result Options Window Use the Results Options window to individually select the types of results and options you want to display in your results report, whether it is displayed in the regular Universal Analysis report form or in a spreadsheet.

Url.Title: Sample Size Window
Url.Abstract: Sample Size Window Use this window to enter a non-zero sample size. This is required to certain types of peak analyses.

Url.Title: Scale Bar Window
Url.Abstract: Scale Bar Window Use this window to set up the scale bar (a labeled I-bar that denotes a unit of distance).

Url.Title: Select Directory Window
Url.Abstract: Select Directory Window Use this window to locate a specific directory.

Url.Title: Open Data File Window
Url.Abstract: Open Data File Window Use this window to select a data file. Follow the instructions below to understand and use this window.

Url.Title: Analyze Sensitivity Window
Url.Abstract: Analyze Sensitivity Window The Sensitivity option allows you to analyze curve sensitivity using a least-squares averaging technique. The curve data is reread from the data file, smoothed using the analysis region window, and subtracted from the original raw data. The resultant plot is a measure of the signal sensitivity during any portion of the experiment.

Url.Title: Smooth Curve Window
Url.Abstract: Smooth Curve Window The Smooth option allows you to smooth curves using a least-squares averaging technique. Normal curves are smoothed versus the X-axis signal, and derivative curves are smoothed versus the X-axis signal with respect to which the derivative was taken. Integral curves cannot be smoothed. We recommend that you perform smoothing before any analysis functions.

Url.Title: Temperature Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Temperature Limits Window Use this window to limit the data used for analysis to a specific temperature range.

Url.Title: Time Limits Window
Url.Abstract: Time Limits Window Use this window to limit the data used for analysis to a specific time range. The program scans the data file between the points you specify, then determines the autoscaling factors for the plot. Any data outside these limits is not plotted or analyzed, regardless of the scaling factors you select later.

Url.Title: Transition Label Window
Url.Abstract: Transition Label Window Use this window to enter an identification label for the transition that will be displayed on the graph with the results of the current analysis.

Url.Title: X/Y Transform Window
Url.Abstract: X/Y Transform Window Use the X/Y Transform Window to enter the desired values into the general equation that the program will use to perform the linear transformation, which adjusts the slope and/or intercept of the selected X or Y-axis signal.

Url.Title: Delete Button
Url.Abstract: Delete Button Click this button to remove the selected option.

Url.Title: Last Button
Url.Abstract: Last Button Use this button on the Select File window as follows: If you have multiple files open in Universal Analysis and want to use a report template that calls for fewer files, you can go through the process of identifying the appropriate files, clicking the OK button each time. Then, when you have reached the last file to be identified for output, click the Last button and you will not be prompted to identify any more files.

Url.Title: Move Down Button
Url.Abstract: Move Down Button Click this button once to move the item down one position.

Url.Title: Move Up Button
Url.Abstract: Move Up Button Click this button once to move the item up one position.

Url.Title: Checkbox Auto Fit Spreadsheet Columns
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Auto Fit Spreadsheet Columns Check this box to automatically provide the best fit for the columns and rows generated on your final custom report when a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet object is inserted in a new template.

Url.Title: Checkbox Position Locked
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Position Locked Check the Position Locked box to make the selected report object stay in its current position. You will notice that the position entry fields are grayed out when this box is checkedthis it to prevent moving the object. This locks the object in position, even if you select Edit/Select All and attempt to drag all of the object boxesthe locked box will stay in its position.

Url.Title: Checkbox Snap to Grid
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Snap to Grid Check this box to have the object boxes automatically aligned with the grid dots when inserted. The boxes will "snap" to line up with the grid dots. This function is good for aligning object boxes more precisely.

Url.Title: Checkbox Transparent
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Transparent Check this box to make the background of an object transparent or "see-through" for any objects behind it in the final Microsoft Word® custom report. For example, if you check this box for a Text object, you can position the text label over a curve and the curve will show through the background of the text characters.

Url.Title: Checkbox Visible in Report
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Visible in Report Check this box to make the object box lines appear around the perimeter of the inserted object in the final Microsoft Word® custom report. For example, if this is checked, a box will be drawn around a Normal Plot in the final custom report.

Url.Title: Checkbox Visible Editor Grid
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Visible Editor Grid Check this box to have a dotted grid displayed on the Custom Report Editor window. The grid helps you to align the object boxes when creating a custom report template.

Url.Title: Checkbox List Vertical
Url.Abstract: Checkbox List Vertical Check this box to list any numerical parameters vertically. Leave this box blank to list any numerical parameters horizontally.

Url.Title: Checkbox Automatic Print
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Automatic Print Check this box to have the program automatically print a custom report when a template name is selected from the View/Custom Report menu.

Url.Title: Checkbox Show Report Creation
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Show Report Creation Check this box to have the program show the creation of a custom report in Microsoft Word® regardless of whether the custom report is printed automatically (see Checkbox Automatic Print) or manually (see Print (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)).

Url.Title: Checkbox Show Name
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Show Name Check this box to include the name of the individual parameter on the custom report. First highlight the desired parameter and check or uncheck this box.

Url.Title: Checkbox Show Spreadsheet Grid
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Show Spreadsheet Grid Check this box to show a grid on your final custom report when a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet object is inserted in a new template.

Url.Title: Box (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Box (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Edit/Box option to make changes to the box around the perimeter of the selected report object. When you select this option the Box Options window is displayed to allow you to make changes.

Url.Title: Copy (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Copy (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Copy option to copy the information to the clipboard for retrieval by the Edit/Paste option. You can copy an entire report object if desired.

Url.Title: Cut (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Cut (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Cut option to remove information and place it on the clipboard for retrieval by the Edit/Paste option.

Url.Title: Delete (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Delete (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Delete option to delete the selected report object.

Url.Title: File Number (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: File Number (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the File Number option to enter or change the file number that is used to generate the selected (highlighted) report object. The files are numbered in the order that they are opened. When you select Edit/File Number, the File Number window is displayed.

Url.Title: Font (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Font (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Font option to access the Font window, which allows you to select a font, font type, font size, font color, and effects that will be applied to the highlighted report object.

Url.Title: Overlay Number (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Overlay Number (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Select this option to edit the number of the curve overlay plot inserted as an object in a custom report. First highlight the curve overlay object, then either select Edit/Overlay Number or right click and select Overlay Number. The Overlay Number window is displayed to allow you to change the plot number that will be used when the custom report is output.

Url.Title: Params (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Params (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Select this option to edit the parameters of the report object. The window that is displayed when Edit/Params is selected depends on the report object being edited. Click on the window name next to the object to find out more about editing it.

Url.Title: Paste (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Paste (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Paste option to retrieve any information placed on the clipboard.

Url.Title: Position Locked (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Position Locked (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Select (check) the Position Locked menu item to make the select report object stay in its current position. You will notice that the position entry fields are grayed out when this box is checkedthis it to prevent moving the object. This locks the object in position, even if you select Edit/Select All and attempt to drag all of the object boxesthe locked box will stay in its position.

Url.Title: Select All (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Select All (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Select All option to select (highlight) all of the report objects displayed.

Url.Title: Send to Back (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Send to Back (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use this function to place one report object behind another, effectively layering them. Highlight the desired report object and select Edit/Send to Back.

Url.Title: Snap to Grid (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Snap to Grid (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Select (check) Snap to Grid to have the object boxes automatically aligned with the grid dots when inserted. The boxes will "snap" to line up with the grid dots. This function is good for aligning object boxes more precisely.

Url.Title: Spreadsheet (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Spreadsheet (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Select this option to edit the parameters of a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet object. First highlight the desired spreadsheet object(s) on the template, then select Edit/Spreadsheet. The Spreadsheet Options window is displayed to allow you to change certain parameters of the final spreadsheet custom report.

Url.Title: Undo (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu)
Url.Abstract: Undo (Custom Report Editor/Edit Menu) Use the Undo option to cancel the last action performed.

Url.Title: Close (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Close (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Close menu item to close the current report template file. You will be prompted to save the template to a file (.uat file) before the template is closed.

Url.Title: Export to Word (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Export to Word (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Export to Word menu item to open the report template file in the Microsoft Word® program. Once it is opened in that program, all of the functions in Microsoft Word will be available to edit the report further as desired.

Url.Title: New (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: New (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the New menu item to create a new template file.

Url.Title: Next Report Page (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Next Report Page (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Select the Next Report Page option to specify the path and filename of a Universal Analysis template file (.uat) that will describe the next page of the custom report generated.

Url.Title: Open (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Open (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Open menu item to open an existing report template file.

Url.Title: Print (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Print (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use this command to print a document. This command presents a Print dialog box where you may specify the range of pages to be printed, the number of copies, the destination printer, and other printer setup options.

Url.Title: Print Setup (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Print Setup (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use this command to select a printer and a printer connection. This command presents a Print Setup dialog box, where you specify the printer and its connection. You can also specify the page orientation of both the Custom Report Editor template and the final printed custom report.

Url.Title: Save (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Save (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Save menu item to save the current custom report template to a template file. The template files are saved with the extension .uat. The program will place the template files in the report directory specified on the Main Options  Directory Page.

Url.Title: Save As (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Save As (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Save As menu item to save the current custom report template with a new name or in a new location. The template files are saved with the extension .uat. The program will place the template files in the report directory specified on the Main Options  Directory Page unless a different directory is specified.

Url.Title: Word Template (Custom Report Editor/File Menu)
Url.Abstract: Word Template (Custom Report Editor/File Menu) Use the Word Template function to base your custom report, when it is generated, on an existing Microsoft Word® template file. When this menu item is selected you can browse for and select a Word (.dot) file using the Word Template window.

Url.Title: Help on Custom Report (Custom Report Editor/Help Menu)
Url.Abstract: Help on Custom Report (Custom Report Editor/Help Menu) Use this function to access help on the Custom Report Editor program.

Url.Title: Help Topics (Custom Report Editor/Help Menu)
Url.Abstract: Help Topics (Custom Report Editor/Help Menu) Use this menu item to display the topics available in the online help associated with the entire Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Analysis Log Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Analysis Log Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Insert/Analysis Log function to insert an object into the template that represents a report listing the analysis log for a data file. The Analysis Log allows you to view all of the steps used to manipulate and view the data for an open data file.

Url.Title: Clipboard Text Object
Url.Abstract: Clipboard Text Object Use the Insert/Clipboard Text function to create a report object that will extract text from the clipboard as the report is being generated, and then print that text on your custom report. The text to be reported must be stored on the clipboard prior to launching the custom report. The text can be generated by any mechanism, including a Copy operation or a macro that builds custom report text on the clipboard.

Url.Title: Data Table Report Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Data Table Report Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Data Table/Report function to insert an object into the template that represents the data table in a written report form. When you select this item from the Custom Report Editor insert menu, the Data Table Limits window is displayed. After you enter and accept the values on this window, the object block is inserted into the template. It can be moved, resized, and formatted as desired.

Url.Title: Data Table Spreadsheet Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Data Table Spreadsheet Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Data Table/Spreadsheet function to insert an object into the template that represents the data table in a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet form. When you select this item from the Custom Report Editor insert menu, the Data Table Limits window is displayed. After you enter and accept the values on this window, the object block is inserted into the template. It can be moved, resized, and formatted as desired.

Url.Title: File Text Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: File Text Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Insert/File Text function to locate and select a file that contains text that will be inserted as a report object into your custom report template then printed on your custom report.

Url.Title: Image File (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Image File (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Insert/Image function to locate and select a graphics file to insert into your custom report template.

Url.Title: Method Log Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Method Log Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Insert/Method Log function to insert an object into the template that represents a report listing the method segments that were used to obtain the data file. Each experimental method is made up of a group of segments, which are preprogrammed instructions that are sent to the analytical instrument.

Url.Title: Parameter Report Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Parameter Report Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Parameter/Report function to insert an object into the template that represents a report listing of the experimental parameters (which were used when obtaining the data stored in the data file).

Url.Title: Parameter Spreadsheet Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Parameter Spreadsheet Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Parameter/Spreadsheet function to insert an object into the template that represents, in a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet form, the experimental parameters (which were used when obtaining the data stored in the data file).

Url.Title: Normal Plot Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Normal Plot Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Plot/Normal function to insert an object into the template that represents a normal plot of the current state of the plotted data file.

Url.Title: Overlay Plot Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Overlay Plot Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Plot/Overlay function to insert an object into the template that represents a curve overlay plot, which was generated using the Graph/Overlay functions. See Overlay for information on creating a curve overlay plot.

Url.Title: Results Report Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Results Report Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Results/Report function to insert an object into the template that represents the results of your analysis in a written report form.

Url.Title: Results Spreadsheet Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Results Spreadsheet Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Results/Spreadsheet function to insert an object into the template that represents the results of your analysis in a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet.

Url.Title: Text Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Text Object (Custom Report Editor/Insert Menu) Use the Insert/Text function to enter or import text that will be inserted as a report object into your custom report template then printed on your custom report.

Url.Title: Entry Line Thickness
Url.Abstract: Entry Line Thickness Enter the desired thickness for the object box line that will be displayed and printed in the final custom report when exported to Microsoft Word®. (This color will not be displayed on the report template.)

Url.Title: Entry Box Position Height
Url.Abstract: Entry Box Position Height Use this field to enter the length of the report object boxthis value will set the height of the box in inches. For example, if you enter 4 inches here, the report object will be four inches long when printed.

Url.Title: Entry Box Position Left
Url.Abstract: Entry Box Position Left Enter the amount of inches from the left side of the page that you would like the report object to be positioned. For example, if you enter 2.25 inches here, the box will be positioned two and one half inches from the left side of the page.

Url.Title: Entry Box Position Top
Url.Abstract: Entry Box Position Top Enter the amount of inches from the top of the page that you would like the report object to be positioned. For example, if you enter 2 inches here, the box will be positioned two inches down from the top of the page.

Url.Title: Entry Box Position Width
Url.Abstract: Entry Box Position Width Use this field to enter the width of the report object boxthis value will set the width of the box in inches. For example, if you enter 4 inches here, the report object will be four inches wide when printed.

Url.Title: Entry File Number
Url.Abstract: Entry File Number Enter the desired file number in this entry field. The files are numbered in the order that they are opened in the Universal Analysis program.

Url.Title: Entry Horizontal Origin of Grid
Url.Abstract: Entry Horizontal Origin of Grid Enter the desired numerical value for the horizontal origin of the grid on the Custom Report Editor window. For example, if you enter the horizontal origin of 0.2 inches, the grid will start 0.2 inches down on the template page. This option can be used to set a top margin for the custom report. (In order to see the grid, you must check the Editor Grid Visible box.)

Url.Title: Entry Horizontal Spacing of Grid
Url.Abstract: Entry Horizontal Spacing of Grid Enter the desired numerical value for the amount of space left horizontally between grid dots on the Custom Report Editor window. (In order to see the grid, you must check the Editor Grid Visible box.)

Url.Title: Entry Vertical Origin of Grid
Url.Abstract: Entry Vertical Origin of Grid Enter the desired numerical value for the vertical origin of the grid on the Custom Report Editor window. For example, if you enter the vertical origin of 0.2 inches, the grid will start 0.2 inches from the left side of the template page. This option can be used to set a left side margin for the custom report. (In order to see the grid, you must check the Editor Grid Visible box.)

Url.Title: Entry Vertical Spacing of Grid
Url.Abstract: Entry Vertical Spacing of Grid Enter the desired numerical value for the amount of space left vertically between grid dots on the Custom Report Editor window. (In order to see the grid, you must check the Editor Grid Visible box.)

Url.Title: Entry Custom Report Template File
Url.Abstract: Entry Custom Report Template File Enter the path and filename of a Universal Analysis template file (.uat) that will describe the next page of the custom report generated.

Url.Title: Entry Overlay Number
Url.Abstract: Entry Overlay Number Enter the overlay plot number that will be used when the custom report is output.

Url.Title: Entry Copies
Url.Abstract: Entry Copies Enter the number of copies that will be automatically printed when the checkbox Automatic is selected on the Custom Report Options window.

Url.Title: Entry Spreadsheet Start Column
Url.Abstract: Entry Spreadsheet Start Column Enter the number of the first column that should receive entries when a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet is generated in a custom report.

Url.Title: Entry Spreadsheet Start Row
Url.Abstract: Entry Spreadsheet Start Row Enter the number of the first row that should receive entries when a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet is generated in a custom report.

Url.Title: Entry Excel Template File
Url.Abstract: Entry Excel Template File Enter the location and filename of an existing Microsoft Excel® template file (or click the Browse button to locate one). When the custom report is created, the spreadsheet report object selected will be placed into the Excel file entered here.

Url.Title: Entry Word Template File
Url.Abstract: Entry Word Template File Use this window to enter a Microsoft Word® template file that will be used as a basis for your custom report. When the report is exported to Word, this template will be opened first and then the report will be dynamically created using the Universal Analysis custom report template file and the open data files.

Url.Title: List Arrange Parameters
Url.Abstract: List Arrange Parameters Use this list to arrange the parameters in the order and format desired for your custom report. Use the checkboxes and buttons shown below the list.

Url.Title: List Line Color
Url.Abstract: List Line Color Click on the arrow to the right of the list to select the desired color for the object box line that will be displayed and printed in the final custom report when exported to Microsoft Word®. (This color will not be displayed on the report template.)

Url.Title: List Measurement Units
Url.Abstract: List Measurement Units Click the arrow to the right of the list to select the measurement units to be used in the Custom Report Editor program. These measurement units will apply to the box line thickness, grid spacing and grid origin, which are all selected on the Custom Report Options window.

Url.Title: List Paper Size
Url.Abstract: List Paper Size Select the desired paper size to be used when the report is printed. If your output device has additional paper choices that are not listed in this drop-down list, Universal Analysis does not support them.

Url.Title: List Report Destination
Url.Abstract: List Report Destination Select "Default Printer" for the automatic printing of your custom report from the View/Custom Report menu.

Url.Title: List Spreadsheet Text Alignment
Url.Abstract: List Spreadsheet Text Alignment Select the alignment of the text contained in the cells of a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet when it is placed in a custom report. Choose from general, left, center, or right text alignment.

Url.Title: List Text Alignment
Url.Abstract: List Text Alignment Select a justification option for your text from the drop-down list:

Url.Title: List Fill Color
Url.Abstract: List Fill Color Select the desired color that will fill the text block object when the Custom Report is exported.

Url.Title: List Select Parameters
Url.Abstract: List Select Parameters Use this list to select (check) the parameters that you want to include in your custom report.

Url.Title: New/Edit Custom Report
Url.Abstract: New/Edit Custom Report Use the Custom Report/New menu item to create a new custom report template or edit an existing report. When you select this menu item the Custom Report Editor window is displayed either with a blank window (new) or with the custom report last created (edit).

Url.Title: Radio Buttons Orientation Portrait or Landscape
Url.Abstract: Radio Buttons Orientation Portrait or Landscape

Url.Title: Box Options Window
Url.Abstract: Box Options Window Use this window to set up the box options that will apply to the highlighted report object.

Url.Title: Report Clipboard Text Window
Url.Abstract: Report Clipboard Text Window Use the Report Clipboard Text window to specify the justification, color, and font for clipboard text that will be included in the custom report. Follow the steps below:

Url.Title: Custom Report Options Window
Url.Abstract: Custom Report Options Window Use this window to set up default options that will apply to both the Custom Report Editor program and the way that objects are formatted when first inserted. If you set up these options from this dialog, you can save yourself time when each new custom report template is created.

Url.Title: File Number Window
Url.Abstract: File Number Window Use the File Number option to enter or change the file number that is used to generate the selected (highlighted) report object. The files are numbered in the order that they are opened.

Url.Title: Next Report Page Window
Url.Abstract: Next Report Page Window Use this window to enter or browse for a Universal Analysis template file that will be used as the next page in your custom report.

Url.Title: Overlay Number Window
Url.Abstract: Overlay Number Window The Overlay Number window is displayed when you insert a curve overlay plot object, then select Edit/Overlay Number or right click and select Overlay Number.

Url.Title: Parameter Options Window
Url.Abstract: Parameter Options Window Use this window to selectively choose the parameters that you want to display in your finished custom report. Follow these instructions:

Url.Title: Plot Options Window
Url.Abstract: Plot Options Window Use the Plot Options window to edit the header, axis, footer, etc. that will be placed on the Normal or Overlay Plot included in the custom report. Follow the steps below:

Url.Title: Report Select Text File Window
Url.Abstract: Report Select Text File Window Use the Report Select Text File window to enter or edit the file name and path of the text that will be included in the custom report. Follow the steps below:

Url.Title: Report Text Window
Url.Abstract: Report Text Window Use the Report Text window to enter or edit the text that will be included in the custom report. Follow the steps below:

Url.Title: Select File/Select Overlay Window
Url.Abstract: Select File/Select Overlay Window Use the Select File or Select Overlay window to direct the Custom Report Editor program to the filenames or overlay plot names that correspond with the numbers used for the report objects in the template. The title of the window reflects the number to be applied. For example, if you have a template that uses files or overlay plots numbered 1 and 2, the window displayed when the report is exported will prompt you to "Select File 1" or "Select Overlay 1" and then "Select File 2" or "Select Overlay 2."

Url.Title: Spreadsheet Options Window
Url.Abstract: Spreadsheet Options Window Use this window to edit the parameters of a Microsoft Excel® spreadsheet object on the current template as follows:

Url.Title: Word Template Window
Url.Abstract: Word Template Window Use this window to enter or browse for a Microsoft Word® template file that will be used as a basis for your custom report. When the report is exported to Word, this template will be opened first and then the report will be dynamically created using the Universal Analysis custom report template file and the open data files.

Url.Title: Cannot Find Signals
Url.Abstract: Cannot Find Signals This message is displayed if you try to open a non-TA Instruments data file using Universal Analysis and the program cannot identify the signals. The file will not be opened.

Url.Title: Cannot Fit Negative Data
Url.Abstract: Cannot Fit Negative Data Problem: The humidity weight change data selected for analysis contains negative data values (i.e., weight values below 100%). Fitting of negative weight change data is not supported.

Url.Title: Append (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Append (Autoqueue) Use the Append function to add a record to the end of the list in the autoqueue. You can use this option to change the data file, macro file, or macro used in an appended record.

Url.Title: Copy (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Copy (Autoqueue) Use the Copy menu item to copy a record from the autoqueue to the clipboard for retrieval by pasting.

Url.Title: Cut (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Cut (Autoqueue) Use the Cut menu item to remove a selected record from an autoqueue and simultaneously copy it to the clipboard for retrieval by pasting. This process of cutting and pasting can be used to rearrange the records contained in the autoqueue. The records are processing beginning with the first record in the list when File/Run is selected from the Autoqueue menu.

Url.Title: Delete (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Delete (Autoqueue) Select Delete to delete the selected record. (If you want to copy a record to the clipboard rather than delete it, use the Edit/Cut option in the Autoqueue menu.)

Url.Title: Modify (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Modify (Autoqueue) Use the Modify function to edit a record. You can use this option to change the data file, macro file, or macro used in a particular record.

Url.Title: Paste (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Paste (Autoqueue) Use the Paste menu item to insert the record, which was previously copied to the clipboard (using either Cut or Copy), into the autoqueue at the selected place.

Url.Title: Paste At End (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Paste At End (Autoqueue) Use the Paste At End menu item to insert the record, which was previously copied to the clipboard (using either Cut or Copy), into the autoqueue at the end of the list of records.

Url.Title: Select All (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Select All (Autoqueue) Use the Select All Labels option to highlight all of the records contained in the autoqueue. You can then cut, copy, or delete all of the records.

Url.Title: Auto Run (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Auto Run (Autoqueue) The Auto Run menu item toggles on and off (check/uncheck) to select or cancel the time out feature used for automatic processing (autoanalysis) of the autoqueue records.

Url.Title: Clear Log (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Clear Log (Autoqueue) Use this command to delete all of the records in the autoqueue log.

Url.Title: Import (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Import (Autoqueue) Use the Import menu item to import records from an exported (and renamed) autoqueue file into the autoqueue (AutoQ.txt). When you select Import, an open file window is displayed. This allows you to locate and open an exported autoqueue file. The imported records will be appended to the bottom of the existing records.

Url.Title: Print (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Print (Autoqueue) Use this command to print the autoqueue records. This command presents a Print dialog box where you may specify the range of pages to be printed, the number of copies, the destination printer, and other printer setup options. The format of the printed plot is determined by the current settings for the Printer Destination on the Export Plot window.

Url.Title: Print Setup (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Print Setup (Autoqueue) Use this command to select a printer and a printer connection. This command presents a Print Setup dialog box, where you specify the printer and its connection.

Url.Title: Run (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Run (Autoqueue) Use the Run menu item to process (autoanalyze) the records contained in the autoqueue, beginning with the first record.

Url.Title: Export (Autoqueue)
Url.Abstract: Export (Autoqueue) Use the Export menu item to export the autoqueue file to save it for later recall or reuse. When you select Export, an open file window is displayed, allowing you to rename and save the autoqueue file. (There can only be one autoqueue file (AutoQ.txt), therefore, you must rename the exported autoqueue file.)

Url.Title: Checkbox Append Clipboard (Macro Dialog)
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Append Clipboard (Macro Dialog) Check this box to append the current contexts of the clipboard to the dialogs display text. This provides a means to add numeric values or other dynamically created text to the dialog display text. If the display text field is blank, the only text displayed in the dialog will be that taken from the clipboard.

Url.Title: Checkbox Beep (Macro Dialog)
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Beep (Macro Dialog) Check the Beep box to sound a beep as the dialog opens

Url.Title: Checkbox Clear
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Clear Check this box, if you want to clear the edit field (discard any existing clipboard text).

Url.Title: Checkbox Horizontal Scroll Bar
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Horizontal Scroll Bar Check this box, if you want the edit field to have a horizontal scroll bar.

Url.Title: Checkbox Leading Space (Marco Dialog)
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Leading Space (Marco Dialog) Check this box to insert a space between the display text and any appended clipboard text.

Url.Title: Checkbox Line terminator
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Line terminator Check the Line terminator box, if you want to append an optional carriage return and line feed (<crlf>) line terminator to the copied text.

Url.Title: Checkbox round to integer
Url.Abstract: Checkbox round to integer Check the Round to integer box, if you want to round the value, copied to the clipboard, to the nearest integer and suppress the decimal point.

Url.Title: Checkbox Vertical Scroll Bar
Url.Abstract: Checkbox Vertical Scroll Bar Check this box, if you want the edit field to have a vertical scroll bar.

Url.Title: Debugging Macros
Url.Abstract: Debugging Macros After you have finished capturing a macro, you may run it only to find that it does not execute the way you expected. Errors can occur with the macro process due to the following:

Url.Title: Record
Url.Abstract: Record A record consists of the following: The figure below shows one record in the autoqueue. It is recommended that you process the queue on a regular basis and not allow the autoqueue to build up to an unmanageable number. Once the queue records exceed the maximum allowed, any new records will not be added to the queue.

Url.Title: Entry Autoqueue Comment
Url.Abstract: Entry Autoqueue Comment Enter the desired comment to be displayed in the autoqueue record. This information is for display purposes only. The comment usually (by default) reflects the date and time the record was added to the autoqueue. It can be edited as desired.

Url.Title: Entry Autoqueue Data File
Url.Abstract: Entry Autoqueue Data File Enter or use the Browse button to find the location and name of the data file to be used for autoanalysis.

Url.Title: Entry Autoqueue Macro File
Url.Abstract: Entry Autoqueue Macro File Enter or use the Browse button to find the location and name of the macro file to be used for autoanalysis.

Url.Title: Entry Autoqueue Macro Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Autoqueue Macro Name Use this list to locate and select the macro that you want to use (from the macro file displayed) to perform the autoanalysis.

Url.Title: Entry Edit Field Columns
Url.Abstract: Entry Edit Field Columns Enter the number of Columns to display in the edit field (this defines the Horizontal size of the edit field).

Url.Title: Entry Edit Field Lines
Url.Abstract: Entry Edit Field Lines Enter the number of Lines to display in the edit field (this defines the vertical size of the edit field).

Url.Title: Entry Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Text Enter a Text string of up to 30 characters, which will be appended to the end of the value when it is copied. If no variable name is specified, then only the text string is copied.

Url.Title: Entry Macro Column
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Column Enter the desired column number for the grid selection. For example, you can modify the symbols used in a graph by selecting the grid position of the desired symbol.

Url.Title: Entry Macro Comment
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Comment Enter the desired comment to add to the currently displayed macro. The maximum length of each line is 60 characters and up to 30 lines of text can be entered for a single comment. The comment is identified by " / / " in front of the entered text.

Url.Title: Entry Macro Delay Time
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Delay Time Enter the time, in seconds, that you wish to delay the macro before it automatically continues running the next step.

Url.Title: Entry Description
Url.Abstract: Entry Description Enter a more detailed description for your new macro and its functions (maximum 300 characters).

Url.Title: Entry Macro Display Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Display Text Enter the text to be displayed in the dialog (up to a maximum of 30 characters).

Url.Title: Entry Macro Extended Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Extended Text Edit the text displayed in the field as desired. The pop-up edit menu is available for cutting, copying, pasting, etc. when you right click with the pointer over the entry field.

Url.Title: Entry File
Url.Abstract: Entry File Enter the path and filename for the desired file or use the Browse button to locate and select a file.

Url.Title: Entry Macro Initialization File
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Initialization File Enter the path and filename for the desired initialization file or use the Browse button to locate and select an initialize file.

Url.Title: Entry Jump Step
Url.Abstract: Entry Jump Step Enter the step that you want the macro to jump to.

Url.Title: Text (Macro Dialog)
Url.Abstract: Text (Macro Dialog) Enter the desired text to be displayed on your macro dialog. You can enter up to 10 lines of 60 characters each.

Url.Title: Entry macro modify value
Url.Abstract: Entry macro modify value Enter the desired variable value in this field, then click OK. The change is applied immediately. The Macro Watch List window shows the current value of a macro variable. The Modify Value function changes the variables value, which is then displayed in the Macro Watch List window.

Url.Title: Entry Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Name Enter the name of the macro (maximum 30 characters).

Url.Title: Entry Macro Row
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Row Enter the desired row number for the grid selection. For example, you can modify the symbols used in a graph by selecting the grid position of the desired symbol.

Url.Title: Entry Significant figures
Url.Abstract: Entry Significant figures Enter the number of significant figures for the value that will be copied from the clipboard. If the Round to Integer checkbox is selected, then this entry field is unavailable (grayed out).

Url.Title: Entry Macro Text
Url.Abstract: Entry Macro Text Enter the desired text, then select OK. The macro step will be modified accordingly.

Url.Title: Entry macro value
Url.Abstract: Entry macro value The value entry can be a specific integer assigned to the variable or it can be a value that will direct the program to insert a specific number from a list specified by the variable.

Url.Title: Entry Variable Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Variable Name Use the following guidelines when entering the variable names:  Variables names can only have alphabetic characters, numbers, underline character (underbar), and square brackets (to enclose an optional index which must be a simple variable name or number).

Url.Title: Entry X
Url.Abstract: Entry X Enter the desired x-axis coordinate for the modified step.

Url.Title: Entry Y
Url.Abstract: Entry Y Enter the desired y-axis coordinate for the modified step.

Url.Title: Entry Report Name
Url.Abstract: Entry Report Name Enter the desired name for your customer report template file.

Url.Title: Figure Example Macros
Url.Abstract: Figure Example Macros

Url.Title: Action
Url.Abstract: Action Select the action that you want to be performed after your message dialog response has occurred from the following list:

Url.Title: List condition
Url.Abstract: List condition Click on the arrow to display a drop-down list of conditions that will be applied to the testing of the variable. You will also need to enter a value assigned to the variable and an action that will be taken when the condition is met.

Url.Title: Dialog Type (Macro Dialog)
Url.Abstract: Dialog Type (Macro Dialog) Select the desired dialog type from the following list: See also:

Url.Title: Jump To List
Url.Abstract: Jump To List Select the "Jump To" option you want to insert into your macro from one of the following:

Url.Title: List macro assign operation
Url.Abstract: List macro assign operation Most of the operations listed in the drop-down list are straight-forward mathematical functions. The operations Clipboard (variable, value) or Clipboard (value) are used to copy a specific number from a list copied to the clipboard and ignore the remaining numbers. For example, you can copy the first dimension of a DMA sample from the clipboard by assigning a variable named "size," selecting Clipboard (variable, value), and entering "1" as the value.

Url.Title: Message Response (Macro Dialog)
Url.Abstract: Message Response (Macro Dialog) Select the desired response to your message text from the following list:

Url.Title: List of Macros to Import
Url.Abstract: List of Macros to Import Check the box next to any macro name that you want to import into the existing macro file.

Url.Title: List Test Action
Url.Abstract: List Test Action Click on the arrow to display a drop-down list of available actions. Jump to start– When you select this action, after the condition has been met, the macro will jump to its first step and begin running again.

Url.Title: List variable name
Url.Abstract: List variable name This is a drop-down list of variables that can be found in the currently open macro. Select a variable to add to the Macro Watch List window for debugging purposes.

Url.Title: Assign Clipboard (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Assign Clipboard (Macro Insert Menu) The Assign Clipboard function is used to insert a macro step that will to copy the current value of a macro variable and/or a text string to the clipboard. This is useful for building custom annotations and tables that are placed on a plot or added to a report. The number of significant figures for the copied value can be specified, as well as whether the value should be rounded to an integer. An optional text string of up to 30 characters can be appended to the end of the value when it is copied. If no variable name is specified, then only the text string is copied. An optional carriage return and line feed (<crlf>) line terminator can be appended to the copied text.

Url.Title: Assign Variable (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Assign Variable (Macro Insert Menu) The Assign Variable macro step is used to store a numeric value into a macro variable. The numeric value to be assigned may come from a numeric constant, a number already stored in another macro variable, or a number loaded from the clipboard. The assign step can also be used to add, subtract, multiply, or divide the value of a variable by another value, or to apply a function (such as square root) to the value of a variable.

Url.Title: Beep (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Beep (Macro Insert Menu) Select the Beep option to insert a beeping sound between two steps of a macro. Select the desired position for the beep before selecting this option.

Url.Title: Close All Files (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Close All Files (Macro Insert Menu) Select the Close All Files option to insert a macro step that will automatically close any open data files without prompting the person running the macro. If no files are currently open, the Close All Files step will have no effect.

Url.Title: Comment (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Comment (Macro Insert Menu) Use this menu item to access the Macro Comment window, which allows you to add a comment to the currently displayed macro. The comment appears in the macro steps and is identified by " / / " in front of the entered text. Comment steps in an executing macro are skipped over and produce no action or display. They are for documentation purposes only.

Url.Title: Delay (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Delay (Macro Insert Menu) Select the Delay option to insert a time delay between two macro steps. When you select this option the Macro Delay window is displayed. Select the desired position for the delay before selecting this option.

Url.Title: Dialog (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Dialog (Macro Insert Menu) Use the Dialog option to add a message box to your macro. This option allows you to display informational text and, based on the way the dialog is configured, you can create branching based on a response, provide a repeat mechanism, allow operator intervention to select analysis limits, etc.

Url.Title: Edit Clipboard (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Edit Clipboard (Macro Insert Menu) The Edit Clipboard macro step is used to display a dialog box in which you can view and edit the contents of the Windows clipboard. This is useful for entering custom text or multiple parameter values.

Url.Title: Edit Variable (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Edit Variable (Macro Insert Menu) The Edit Variable macro step is used to display a dialog box in which you can view and edit the contents of a macro variable. This is useful for entering or changing a result or macro parameter. See also: Macro Edit Variable Window.

Url.Title: Exit Program (Macro Insert Menu)
Url.Abstract: Exit Program (Macro Insert Menu) Select the Exit Program option to insert a step that automatically causes the Universal Analysis program to close. Any messages that are needed, such as the option to save any changes to the macros, will be displayed as usual. Select the desired position for the stop before selecting this option.

Url.Title: File Name (Macro Insert Menu)
